text: Flying over American heartland. We see the earth through pilot's perspective as sky and ground swap positions, the plane swooping down and storming over the ground.

is a biplane, racing over a field lush with young plants. releases a trail of crop spray, and climbs again... Up into a crystalline blue sky where sunshine pours like honey over family farms stretching to the horizon. Maybe it's not heaven, maybe it's just Tennessee. But as long a there's been an America, men have fought and died for thi place -- as volunteers.  Far off, but visible from the plane is

The barn is unpainted except for hand lettering that says "McCawley Crop Dusting." Another plane noise, this one ma by kids, brings us to TWO BOYS, sitting in the shell of a old plane propped on crates, scavenged of it's engine, se and wheels. The boys sit in it's cockpit, butts crowded onto the nail they've replaced the seat with. They've even attached a 2 as propeller, as if their imaginations needed any help. T wear overalls and have bowl haircuts: RAFE and DANNY, 10 years old.
Bandits at 2 o'clock.
Power dive! They buzz their lips in a flying noise and work the contr Rafe's bare feet on one pedal, Danny's on the other.
It's Germans!
Kill the bastards! Rafe looks at Danny in shock -- then they both laugh and right back into their game, manufacturing their own machi gun and engine sounds.
Good shooting, Danny!
Good shooting, Rafe!
Land of the free...
Home of the brave!

There's another one! Their vocal motors roar again... But a man's hand grabs D by the straps of his overalls and jerks him from the cock It's Danny's FATHER and he's a fearsome sight; drunk, his hair uncombed, his face unshaven, his teeth -- those stil left -- are rotting. He's also missing an arm; but the on that's left is potent, and he's shaking Danny with it.
You no count boy! Johnson come lookin', said he'd pay a dime for you to shovel his pig shed, and I can't find you no place.

Daddy, I told you I was comin' here. His father slaps him off his feet. Rafe is so horrified h can't get a sound out. Danny isn't even surprised. But wh his father snatches him up again, twisting the overall st so tight they choke him, he struggles. It does no good; h father starts marching across the field, dragging and strangling Danny.

Da!... Dad... The father's drunken anger makes him oblivious -- until CRACK! The 2x4 propeller slams him across the back, knock him to the ground and making him drop Danny. The father rolls over to see 10-year-old Rafe, holding th 2x4 like a bat.
Let him alone! The father's eyes bulge in rage; he struggles to his feet
Rafe... Daddy... No! The man looks murderous, but Rafe draws back the board.

I'll bust you open, you...German! The words ring something deep in the man's booze-broken brain. He begins to cough, convulsively; it brings a blos of blood to his mouth. He wipes it with his hand, but blo clings to his teeth. He chokes out --

I fought the Germans. He looks at Danny in shame, with the realization of what just done. He turns and staggers away. Danny looks at Rafe -- a communication between boys joine something deeper than blood. Then Danny runs off after hi father.
Daddy! Daddy! wait. Danny catches him, takes his father's hand, and walks aw with him. The crop duster we saw in the air has just landed, behind Rafe. The pilot, RAFE'S FATHER, shuts off the engine.
What's goin' on, son?
Nothing. Danny's Dad just come to get him. Rafe turns back to the ramshackle plane and replaces the propeller. His father looks toward Danny and his father, walking away, then looks at his own son.
Hey, boy -- you wanna go up? Rafe can't believe it; he runs to the plane and hops into father's lap. As his father cranks the engine and tucks h into the harness, Rafe says --
Daddy, sometime will you take Danny up too?
Sure will, son. The engine races to life...and we --

American P-40 fighters blast through the air, props screa and wind singing by their wings. There are eight pilots in their individual seats, and we focus on two: RAFE MCCAWLEY has grown lean and handsome. And DANNY WALKER is very much the same. Their planes start swapping positions in the formation; w the other guys are flying along in a tight line, Rafe and Danny are playing, one of them gunning his engine to go h the other diving and coming back up in his place, leapfrogging. It scares the other guys, having their planes flashing in out, so close. The TRAINING CAPTAIN, watching through binoculars on the ground, talks into his RADIO --
McCawley! Walker! Cut that out!
I thought this was a training flight. I'm just trying to give Danny some training.

Not on your best day, boy! Rafe grins and guns his plane low, in the opposite direct he was moving before. Danny reacts almost instantly... leapfrogging in the opposite direction, scaring the piss of everybody else.
That's it, get into a wedge! The squadron responds, forming up into a tight V, Rafe an Danny just behind and on either side of the center.
Didn't you say test the limits?

Hey, you wanna test my limits, you better line up a couple dozen women on the GROUND...cause I got NO limits in the air! Rafe grins, loving the challenge. Then he and Danny do th leapfrogging maneuver laterally, swapping sides in the v.
Everybody down!
The planes land in tight order and taxi off the runway; s down their props, slide back the canopies and hop down. W see young pilots we'll get to know: ANTHONY, BILLY, RED.
Where are McCawley and Walker?
They've circled to opposite ends of the airfield and are heading right at each other, like two bullets playing chicken.
Aw shit...

From Rafe and Danny's POV, the rush is awesome. THE PILOTS ON THE GROUND watch in awe as the P-40's get close they can't possibly get out of each other's way. Billy, the most boyish-faced of the pilots, yells to drow out the sound of the collision... At the last instant, both planes snap a quarter turn so t their wings are vertical, and they shoot past each other belly to belly.
Rafe and Danny burst out laughing.
laugh and congratulate each other.
You know what they say... You can take the crop duster out of the country -- but don't put him in a P-40. Rafe banks to land, and Danny tucks in behind him. Danny Rafe's plane in his sights.
If I had guns I'd be chewing up your -- Rafe feints left, banks right, and appears behind Danny.

If you had guns, you'd be pissin’ on ‘em. They're almost to the landing strip, Rafe behind Danny. B as Danny's wheels are about to touch, he guns his engine snaps the nose of his plane straight up. THE OTHER PILOTS stop laughing.
He's doing an inside loop!
Aw, shit... Danny pulls it off, just barely making a full circle to c in behind Rafe and bounce to a stop on the runway.
Yee-hawww!!! Danny taxis his plane over to join the others. He's grinn as he slides back his cockpit cover; then --
Where's Rafe? Red, tall with flaming orange hair, tips his chin toward air. Seeing Rafe's plane still in the air, Danny starts t refasten his harness.
You're down, Walker! That's an order!
What about him?
He's not taking my orders anymore. Danny's just about to ask what the hell that means, when notices Rafe climbing in a deliberate spiral.
He's gonna do it.
Do what?
It. (beat) Aw, shit. Aw shit shit shit... RAFE'S PLANE reaches two thousand feet, just a speck abov them, and seems to pause in the air.
I shouldn't'a done an inside loop. I shouldn't'a done an inside loop.
Why?
Cause now he's gonna do an outside loop.
Aw shit. Aw shit shit shit... Anthony and Billy join in, like an involuntary chant --

Aw shit shit shit... RAFE, IN HIS COCKPIT, is tightly controlled, yet serene. noses the plane into a power dive. The P-40 screams toward the ground, picking up speed, goi so fast it begins to shudder. THE OTHER PILOTS are transfixed. Red is so nervous he can get the words out.
Aw sh- sh- sh- sh-
Shit.
Yeah.

You can do it, Rafe. You can do it. The P-40, hurtling toward the ground at nauseating speed, snaps into a half roll, streaking upside down over the runway. Rafe hangs inverted in his flight harness, the asphalt of the runway shooting past, ten feet beyond his head. He pushes the plane into a climb, his cockpit on the outs of the circle. The plane reaches the top of its arc, and almost stalls; but Rafe noses it over again, toward the earth, only this time he has very little altitude. The pl hurtles down, still with it belly on the inside of the curve... And makes it full circle. Rafe's head now is barely a foo off the asphalt as the plane shoots past, still inverted. THE OTHER PILOTS burst into cheers. RAFE, IN HIS COCKPIT permits himself a smile. He lands, and the guys run out to meet him...all except f the Training Captain, who stands there shaking his head. Danny jumps on the wing, as Rafe stops and slides back hi canopy. Danny grabs him by the harness and shakes him.
You could've killed yourself, you stupid bastard! He dives into the cockpit, hugging Rafe.
That was the most beautiful thing I ever saw.
COLONEL JIMMY DOOLITTLE, mid-forties, is commander of the base. He's as tough as he is good in the air. And right n he's frowning at Rafe McCawley, standing at attention bef him.
There are some people who think the  outside loop is reckless and irresponsible.
How could it be irresponsible, Sir, if you were the first man in the world to do it?
Don't get smart with me, son.

Never, Sir. I just meant it's dangerous only for the kind of pilot who wants to show off, rather than inspire the other pilots in his unit. And all you've done for me, Sir, working out the transfer, I did it to say thanks. To honor you, Sir. What the French call a "homage."
That's bullshit, son. But it's really good bullshit.
Thank you, Sir. Doolittle stands, moves around his desk, and shakes Rafe' hand.
Good luck over there McCawley. I admire your decision.
Thank you, Sir.

The pilots are getting slicked up for a night on the town Danny's at the mirrors with the others; he's putting on cologne, and looks terrific in his uniform. Anthony and Billy are combing their hair at the sinks. Bi declares to his image in the mirror --
You good-lookin' sumbitch...don't you EVER die!
That's your line for tonight, ya know.
What, good-lookin' sumbitch?

No, numbnuts, die. You get your nurse alone, you look her in the eye, and say, "Baby, they're training me for war, and I don't know what'll happen. But if I die tomorrow, I wanna know that we lived all we could tonight." I've never known it to fail. Red finishes brushing his teeth at the sink beside them.
He's n-never known it to work, either. The guys head out laughing, running into Rafe coming in.
Doolittle didn't kill you? Attaboy! Rafe catches Danny's arm.
Danny, there's something I gotta tell you...
Rafe and Danny are walking on the parade ground; the othe guys are already on the bus that will take them into town Danny's upset by what Rafe just told him.
How could you do this?
The Colonel helped me work it out.
I don't mean how'd you do the paperwork, I mean how the hell did you do it without letting me in on it?
I'm sorry, Danny, but they're only accepting the best pilots.
Don't make this a joke, Rafe. You're talking about war, and I know what war does to people.

Danny, you know how many times I saw you come to school with a black eye or a busted nose, and couldn't do a thing about it -- for you, or for your mother... or your father, with his lungs scorched out with mustard gas, and more left of  his lungs than there was of his spirit? You've made your sacrifice, Danny. It's time I made mine.
(from the bus) The nurses are waiting!
Let's go.
Nah, you go on.
I have to talk to Evelyn. And I want you to meet her.

Some other time. I don't feel like a party. Danny walks away. The bus driver's ready to leave, and Re is honking the horn for Rafe to come. Rafe reluctantly le Danny go, and heads for the bus, where the pilots are chanting --
Nurses! Nurses! Nurses!

The trains of 1942 have their own beauty, with felt seats shaded lamps, and paneled compartments even in the econom section. But the glow of the train is outshone by EVELYN STEWART. She's one of ten young women, Army nurses, gathe at one end of the car as it rattles along the track. The other nurses are pretty and ripe -- maybe a bit too ripe. Their lips painted bright red, their faces powdered their spirits high. Evelyn listens in amusement to BETTY, a cute blonde with unmissable boobs, and BARBARA, a burnette equally endowed
Do you have trouble with your boobs in the uniform?
You mean hiding them?
Hide them? On a date with pilots? I'm talking about how you make them show! SANDRA, another nurse, speaks up.
Loan 'em to me, I'll make 'em show.

The boobs or the pilots? The girls laugh and shove each others' knees; it's a part wherever they go. But Evelyn can't keep her mind on the frivolity. She looks out the window and her thoughts drif away.
We'll ask Evelyn. Evelyn? Evelyn!
000, she's thinking of her date! Come on, you've been dating a pilot. We want to know what we can expect. Suddenly all the girlish faces are looking at Evelyn.
I've been dating one pilot. And only for a few weeks. But I know he's different from all the others. Sandra throws up her arms and swoons onto her friends.
True love!...
Morphine, give her morphine!
Give her an enema.

But I do have a warning for you. There's one line you all need to know, and you're likely to hear it from any man in a uniform. It goes like this: "Honey, Baby... We never know what's gonna happen, and I may die tomorrow...so, let's live all we can tonight." A silence among the nurses.
I tell you. Any one of those arrogant, leather-jacketed, slick-lookin' flyboys tries that line on me...he's gonna get anything he wants. As the nurses laugh --

Our pilots -- indeed leather-jacketed and handsome -- are waiting on the platform. Among then is Rafe, holding something behind his back, as the train pulls in and shud to a stop, clouds of steam jetting onto the platform and giving the moment a dream-like haze.
The nurses start stepping out; both pilots and nurses pre surprise to see each. At the door of the train, Evelyn whispers to Betty --
Stick with me, I'll find you somebody good. Betty spot's Rafe.
I'll take that one.
He's taken. But come on, I'll introduce you. They move to Rafe; he crosses the platform to meet them, eyes holding Evelyn.
Hello, Lieutenant. Good to see you.
You too, Lieutenant. Betty clears her throat.
Oh, this is Betty.
Nice to meet you, Betty. He draws his hand from behind his back; he's holding two roses. He hands one to Evelyn and the second to Betty.
Danny would'a brought this. He escorts them along the platform.
Danny's not coming?
No, he...got some news today. He'll be  okay, he just didn't feel like coming tonight.
I was hoping to meet him.
I was hoping to meet him.
We'll just have to find a substitute, won't we? Betty stops, and faces Rafe.
I just want to tell you one thing. If you're thinking this might be your last night on earth?... I'm prepared to make it meaningful. (leaning close) Very meaningful.
At ease, Betty!

It's a party in full swing; swing music, jitterbugging, beautiful young men and women in high spirits. Rafe and Evelyn are sitting at a big table with the other pilots and nurses. Anthony's paired up with Sandra, Billy with Barbara, and Red, shyest of the group, finds himself next to Betty. Betty's already found a companion in Red Strange.
He, I'm R-Red. Red S-Strange.
Red...Strange?
You know the football player, Red G- Grange? Well the guys called me R-Red, cause you know, I'm red...and they thought I was strange, so, you know, Red G-Grange, Red Str-Strange.
But...they called you Strange? Because of Red Grange? I don't get it. Was Red Grange strange?
How would I know. Beside her beer is an open ketchup bottle; he picks it u swigs from that. Rafe and Evelyn see this, and try to kee from laughing.
Do you always stutter?
Only when I'm n-n-n-
Nervous?
Yeah. But if I have to get something out, I c-can always s-s-s- (he sings)
She covers his hand with hers.
Don't be nervous. Red looks at Betty with love in his eyes. Under the table Rafe and Evelyn join hands too.

There shipping us out. Hawaii. The Germans are overrunning Europe, and we're sent to paradise. How about you? Have you heard anything? He hesitates; then Evelyn is distracted by the conversati beside them, between Barbara and Billy.

You're a very special woman, and...well baby, they're training me for war, and we don't know what happens tomorrow. So we gotta make tonight special. Barbara shoots a look at Evelyn, before she answers.

I hope you can back that up, flyboy. Cause you're not ever gonna forget tonight. She takes him by the hand and pulls him to his feet... Th start dancing, sexy movements that won't stop till they'v been in bed. Rafe pulls Evelyn to her feet, and leads her through the dancers, outside.
They find a quiet place on a balcony that overlooks the river, and Manhattan beyond. Evelyn takes in the view, breathes in the air; she still holds the rose.
Whatever you're trying to tell me isn't good, is it. Or it wouldn't be so hard to say.
The only reason it's hard to say is that I keep thinking I don't have the right to say it. But I've got to because it's true. I love you. (beat) That must surprise you.
It surprises me that I'm not the only one on this balcony who feels that way. The power of hearing this from each other grips them both
There's one thing I have to say. I'm going away.
We're all going away.

I'm going to the war. The real war. Hitler's taken Europe. The Brits are hanging on by their fingernails, and If they lose, there'll be more people killed than anybody can imagine. And not just there, but here.
But you're in the U.S. Army, how could you --
Colonel Doolittle pulled the strings, and put me on loan to the R.A.F. They need pilots, and we need experience. I leave tomorrow.
You waited til tonight to tell me?
I had to tell you in person. Because there's something else I need to say.  He studies her face, burning it into his memory.

Evelyn...you know the line -- let's make tonight memorable. What I feel about you makes it impossible for me to say something like that. I£ I don't come back, I don't want to saddle you with regret and sadness you'll carry the rest of your life.
I don't know if you can choose that, Rafe.

Maybe not. But I need you to know. I love you. And I will come back. I'll find a way. And then we'll get a chance to know if what I felt the first moment I saw you, and every minute since then, is real.
Do one thing for me, before you go. She takes his hand and leads him inside.

She leads him onto the dance floor, and they dance, among others, yet in a world apart from everyone else. And then they stop while all the others move around them, and kiss kind of kiss that lasts a lifetime.

The nurses are entering the hotel. Pilots are going in wi them. But Rafe and Evelyn stop on the street. A last kiss. Their hands touch a final time, and then par She moves inside the lobby, and looks out the glass doors he walks away.
Rafe and Danny stand on the platform. Rafe's got his gear packed in a bag slung over his shoulder.
All aboard! Rafe glances once more toward the revolving doors from th station that lead onto the platform.
Didn't you say you told her not to come?
Yeah.
Then why are you looking for her?
It's a test. If I asked her to come and she came, it wouldn't tell me anything. If I tell her not to come, and she comes...then I know she loves me.
You're still a kid, ya know that? Take care of yourself.
You too. Rafe sticks his hand out to Danny. Danny knocks it away, hugs him. Rafe steps onto the train, and it pulls away. Rafe waves. Danny waves back and smiles, but he whispers like a praye
Give 'em hell, Rafe.
Rafe finds a seat and sits down. He's the only one in the car, and he's deeply alone.

Danny walks to one of the three revolving doors back into station. He takes the one on the far right. As he passes through it, he doesn't see Evelyn rushing through the doo the left side. She's told herself she wouldn't come, but couldn't help it, and now as she sees the last car of the train disappearing around the corner the pain of it all h her. She stands on the empty platform, as lonely as Rafe.
Rafe and Evelyn travel in opposite directions, toward opposite ends of the earth...
as Rafe boards a Canadian naval vessel headed into the No  Atlantic.
Evelyn and her fellow nurses ride the train through the American southwest. The scenery outside the window is beautiful, but her thoughts are far away...

Rafe's ship is in a convoy through the rough gray waters. The deck is loaded with military supplies bound for Brita Rafe stands among the drab crates and seems oblivious to rain, his thoughts on Evelyn. He looks toward the eastern horizon, where his ship is heading. A deep, dark storm is brewing before them...

Evelyn stands on the deck of a ship headed in the opposit direction, on another ocean, the sky is clear, the breeze warm, the light of a glowing sunset bathes her face. The MONTAGE ENDS, with them heading to different ends of the earth.

In the eternal dusk of England, everything is cold and gr British fighter planes -- Spitfires and Hurricanes -- are surrounded by mechanics hurriedly ripping off bullet ridd fuselage panels and digging into overworked aircraft engi Rafe walks across the tarmac, still carrying his duffel b He moves up behind a slim, pale BRITISH AIR COMMANDER who surveying engine damage on one of the Spitfires.
Rafe McCawley, Sir. Rafe salutes as the Air Commander turns and then returns salute, with his left arm -- his right arm is gone. Rafe freezes at the sight, reminded of Danny's father.
On loan from Colonel Doolittle, is it?
That's me, Sir.
Good on you, then, Rafe McCawley. We'll get you situated in some quarters, and then introduce you to the equipment you'll be flying.
If you're patching up bullet holes right  here on the runway, maybe we should skip the housekeeping and get right to the planes.
Are all the Yanks as anxious as you are to get yourself killed, Lieutenant?
Not anxious to die, Sir, anxious to matter.

A Spitfire sits on the runway, and it's badly mangled -- string of bullet holes punched through at mid-fuselage; a shot-off chunk of wingtip; but most striking is the blood still splattered over the inside of the cockpit.
Good lad. Didn't die till he'd landed and shut down his engine. Welcome to the war. He walks away, leaving Rafe to stare at the bloody cockpi
Evelyn and the nurses enter the base, riding in two jeeps As they stop at the gate, the guards look at them, especi Evelyn in the lead jeep; one guard mumbles to the other -
I've died and gone to heaven. The guards lift the bar and smile at the nurses. The jeep drive through. The nurses are loving this island paradise already.

You know the ratio of men to women on this island? Four-thousand...to one. Barbara slides on a new pair of sunglasses with plastic p trees glued on the sides, and calls back to the guards as jeeps pull away --
See ya on the beach, boys!
As the other nurses happily unpack, Evelyn leaves and cro the grass in the drenching sunshine. We follow her into -

She finds a small, immaculately clean hospital, twenty b with luminous white sheets, all empty. Then she notices the view. It's of Pearl Harbor, with the entire American Pacific fleet riding at anchor. Battleshi all in a row. Aircraft carriers too, in perfect stillness the aqua blue water with a white sand bottom. The view is expansive and beautiful. The sound of an approaching fighter plane with wing guns firing as we --

location: THE DARK SKIES OVER THE ENGLISH CHANNEL

text: Rafe, in the middle of an aerial dogfight, throws his Spitfire into a tight turn, swinging around to fire again into a squadron of Messerschmidts; they outnumber the Bri planes, and they're tougher and faster. Rafe darts throug their line, machine guns blazing. One of the Spitfires in Rafe's squadron has taken hits in engine compartment and is sputtering, losing power, its pilot, NIGEL, frantic as the German planes swarm into fin him.

I need help! Someone get them off me! Rafe slams his control stick hard right and goes into a p dive at one of the Messerschmidts. Rafe's bullets chew up its cockpit and the plane goes into a fast corkscrew spir down into the water. Rafe instantly climbs again. Nigel, in the moment of safe Rafe has bought him, bails out, his chute blossoming and carrying him toward the water. The OTHER BRITISH PILOTS a impressed.

(into radio) Nigel's out! I'll call in the position! (to himself) That Yank is bloody good. Rafe swings his plane right back at the Germans; he attac them head on, just like he went at Danny, only this time firing his machine guns. And OVER THIS ferocious dogfight, we hear his letter to Evelyn...

Dear Evelyn... It is cold here. So cold, in a way that goes deep into your bones.  The Messerschmidt in Rafe's sights breaks apart with the stream of precise fire he pours into it, its prop flying pieces, its disintegration accelerated by its airspeed. Before it completely comes apart, it explodes. Rafe goes into another tight turn, to get at them again.

It's not easy making friends. Two nights ago I drank a beer with a couple of the R.A.F. pilots -- beer's the only thing here that isn't cold -- and yesterday both of them got killed... As Rafe starts another attack we see him in the cockpit, the trance of battle, as other Spitfires around him are getting shot out of the sky...as we --
Evelyn, receiving the letter at mail call. She sits on the grass under a palm tree, in paradise, rea his letter.
There is one place I can go to find warmth, and that is to think of you.

Evelyn is off duty, and wears a light cotton dress. She's let her hair down, and her skin has the sheen of light sw in the tropical heat. The restaurant is barely more than a shelter of palm wood posts with a frond roof, and it looks out over the harbor Evelyn sits alone. She's brought writing paper. As the Hawaiian waiter serves her an icy tropical ambrosia with chunks of pineapple and a fresh plumeria flower floating the rim of the glass, she lifts her pen. But before she can start to write, three naval officers m over to her table from the bar. They're out of uniform to wearing garish tropical shirts.
A woman beautiful as you shouldn't be sitting alone. Buy you a drink?
Thank you...Ensign. The guys look at each other, impressed that she could tel
Ensign! Smart too!
So how about that drink? Or dinner?
Thank you, but...I really want to be alone right now.
Want to see something long and hard? He shows her the tattoo of an anchor on his forearm. Evel looks away from them, toward the harbor.
I'm sorry. I've got a letter to write.
Cold bitch. His friends start to pull him away, but Evelyn's eyes fla
What did you say?
I said you're cold.
Cold? No, I'm just thinking about a war. And maybe you should be too. They leave, shaking their heads. Evelyn picks up her pen, and writes.

Dear Rafe... It's strange to be so far from you in body, and so close to you in spirit. But if our spirits really give our bodies life, then you should know this: Every night I look at the sunset, and try to draw the last ounce of heat from its long day... She looks toward the sunset now; then she writes again...
Rafe brings his battered plane in for a landing...
Rafe sits on his cot, reading her letter.
...and send it from my heart to yours. Rafe is startled as the Air Commander appears beside his bunk.
Air-Sea Rescue picked up Nigel. He'll be back with us tomorrow. Rafe nods, glad to hear the news. The Commander starts to walk away, then turns back.

Some of us look down on the Yanks for not yet joining this war. I'd just like to say that if there are many more back home like you, God help anyone who goes to war with America. The Commander salutes, with his left hand. And Rafe salut too -- with his left hand.
The White House looks somehow whiter and purer in the glo 1941.

GENERALS, ADMIRALS, and other advisors sit around the polished table -- all males, in suits and in uniforms. Th door opens, and the men all stand. PRESIDENT FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT appears, in a wheelchair, pu by a huge black valet, GEORGE. The President's legs are shriveled, braced with the iron supports that attach to h shoes and are apparent beneath the cloth of his pin-strip pants. From the waist up Roosevelt is heavily muscled, powerful, and handsome even in his little spectacles. The valet rolls him to the head of the table; he's speaking e before he settles in.
Please be seated, gentlemen. They sit, as one.
Churchill and Stalin are asking me what I'm asking you: How long is America going to pretend the world is not at war?
We've increased supply shipments to them, Mr. President, and we're losing merchant vessels every day.
Shift in every destroyer and anti- aircraft weapon you can find.
Sir, our Pacific Fleet is already down to almost nothing.
Gentlemen, at this moment the nation of Hungry has a larger military then the United States. We have no choice but to draw from whatever we can.

The Conference Room is similar to that of the White House But this table is low and all the men sit on the floor. A there are no civilians here; Japan is now a nation ruled its warriors. The last man to enter the room and take his place is ADMI YAMAMOTO. Harvard educated, Yamamoto is an object of veneration and suspicion among the men of the war council Yamamoto bows, sits, and looks across the table at his fr Genda, who can't hide his fear. Yamamoto glances to the f end of the table where NISHIKURA, chief of the War Counci sits glowering. (Their discussion is in Japanese, with subtitles.)
So you join us, Admiral. Some of us thought your education at an American university would make you too weak to fight the Americans.
If knowledge of opponents and careful calculation of danger is taken as weakness then I have misunderstood what it means to be Japanese.

The time has come to strike! Or to sit and let the Americans cut off our oil and our future. I know what you whisper to the others, Yamamoto -- that the Americans are strong. Yet look at their leader. He motions to OYAMA, an intelligence analyst, who opens a file and lays out pictures of Roosevelt.

Franklin Roosevelt. Born into great wealth. Fifteen years ago, he was  stricken with polio. Now he cannot walk, or even stand without help. Photographers will not take pictures of him in his chair; Americans do not wish to know how weak their President is. Yamamoto makes a low grunt.
You have something to say, Yamamoto?

The Council knows I have opposed fighting the Americans. No matter how great our resolve, they have resources beyond ours. If we must go to war, there is only one way -- deal them a blow from which it will take them years to recover. In that time we can conquer all of the Pacific, and they will have no choice but to ask for peace.
You see us as capable of such a blow?

The Americans themselves have made it possible. We will annihilate them in a single attack -- at Pearl Harbor. The members of the war council are so pleased with Yamamo that they bow to him. Only Genda keeps his eyes raised lo enough to see the sadness in Yamamoto's face.
Danny Walker and his pilot buddies have just arrived; the enter the barracks, talking happily.
If I ain't n-never on a b-boat again, it'll be too s-soon.

Where are the women on this -- Danny has stopped before the others; now all of them see the other pilots who inhabit this air base are still in t beds, sleeping off hangovers. They wear Hawaiian shirts; they haven't shaved.
They're s-still asleep! Danny pauses for a moment, then shouts --
Drop your cocks and grab your socks, boys! The terror of the skies are here! The sleeping pilots groan, and cover their heads with the pillows.

They're all drunk. One guy sits up in bed, his hair pointing every direction the compass, his tongue working as if to wipe a terrible taste from his mouth. As his feet dangle over the side of the bunk and one of them touches the floor, a sensation reaches his sotted brain; he raises that foot to look at bottom, and finds a new tattoo, on the sole of his foot; blinks as if trying to remember how it got there. Danny moves over to him, and dubs him with a name, COMA.
Hey. You. Mr. Coma.
Where's that lizard?
What lizard?
The one that slept in my mouth last night.
What the hell happened to you guys? Coma is one of those drunks who speak as if he's always a to burp.
Ever hear of mai-tai's? Comes ina big...pot. Like...like...
A m-missionary?
No, like... Coma emits a pukey, toxic burp that has Danny and his bud wincing back from the fumes.

This is an Air Base? Where's your squad commander? The question soaks through to Coma's brain. His right han points...and his left hand points...in different directio His hands float around in the air until finally both of are indicating the same direction, behind his back. In th bunk beyond Coma's is another drunk pilot in a Hawaiian shirt...and to judge by the shapely bronzed leg that protrudes from under his damp sheet, there's a woman with too. Danny and his buddies are speechless -- except for Red Strange.
I th-think I'm gonna like it here.
You guys are new?
Yeah.

Mai-tai's. I got this to tell ya, about mai-tai's. Coma's head drifts forward slowly; they think for a momen he's looking for something under the bed. Then he pukes. Danny leaps back from the splatter, and marches out of th barracks; his friends follow.
Danny and his buddies stride up to the airfield. It's ful of fighter planes -- and they're all bunched together in clusters on the field. Danny grabs a MECHANIC.
Hey! What is this, the planes all bunched up like that?
The brass is afraid of sabotage. This makes 'em easier to protect -- and easier to service.
What about easier to hit in an air raid?
Who's gonna to that? Japan is four thousand miles away. So you guys just arrived, huh?
Yeah.
We got a saying here. A-low-HA! The mechanic walks off. Danny and the guys are left stan on the tarmac.
Well guys...I reckon there's just one thing to do...

Danny and the pilots are in Hawaiian shirts, their party full swing. A bucket-sized hollowed-out volcano sits in t middle of the table, with twelve straws emerging from the crater. It's full of booze -- or was; Danny and the other guys are pulling heartily at the straws, and they gurgle the last liquid is sucked dry.
More m-mai-tai's! Coma is sitting there with them, beside Red.

Absolutely right. Everybody's having a ball, the new arrivals fitting right with the others. Danny's a bit off to himself, lost in hi own thoughts. Billy and Anthony are doing the hula to the Hawaiian music playing.
No, you guys aren't doing it right. It's in the hands. They talk story. Coma stands and starts demonstrating, explaining the gest of his hula.
Fish swim in ocean... Happy in the Mother Sea... Girl, beautiful girl, with big jugs, walks into water...waves lapping at her thighs...
I never knew those dances were so sophisticated.
...Fish nibble at her breasts... Coma's really into his dance, his hands over enormous imaginary breasts; but as he turns toward the windows --
A more beautiful girl walks by... The guys see Evelyn passing on the other side of the stre gorgeous in the sunshine. Coma's hands start squeezing th  imaginary breasts of his hula.
Hey, isn't that Evelyn? Danny moves up to look.
Rafe's girl, Evelyn?
You guys know her?! I gotta have an intro! Man, I'd like to -- Danny's hand is suddenly around Coma's larynx.

A friend of mine's in love with her. So you don't even look -- not ever. Danny releases him and Coma staggers back to the table to nuzzle up to one of the straws of the mai-tai volcano. Danny looks out the window again and sees Evelyn's beauti form disappear around the corner, on her way back to the hospital. Danny moves back to the table, and as two burly Hawaiian waiters set another full loaded mai-tai volcano the center of the table, he picks up a glass and dips it of the potent liquid. He shouts to the whole room --

I'm a better pilot than any son-of-a- bitch on this island! So I'm the one to say this! Here's to Rafe McCawley! A better pilot...and a better man...than me. The other pilots drink up -- from glasses or from straws.
To Rafe. Danny drains the whole glass at one chug, and slams it do onto the table. Then he blinks, puts a hand on his stomac and frowns. Coma recognizes the look.
Uh oh. Volcanic eruption! Danny bends at the waist; his head obscured by the table.
Shit, he's puking on my feet!
Well, you p-puked on his feet.
Yeah, but he was wearing shoes!
ADMIRAL KIMMEL is Commander of the American Pacific Fleet Two members of his staff are standing uncomfortably in fr of him, having delivered a message from the Joint Chiefs Staff.
...transfer twelve more destroyers to Atlantic Fleet, and all the available anti-aircraft weaponry?! Washington has gone insane! Kimmel's STRATEGIC ANALYST speaks up.
We've done what you ordered, Admiral, and war gamed the likely outcome of a Japanese attack against each of our major bases in the Pacific. Wake, Guam, Midway, the Philippines. In each case, we lose.
You left out Hawaii.
Pearl Harbor can't be attacked effectively from the air. It's too shallow for an aerial torpedo attack. Pearl Harbor's safe. It's everywhere else that we're vulnerable.
Step up surveillance of Japanese communications. They're gonna do something somewhere. I can feel it.

A seaplane takes tourists on an excursion above Pearl Har and around the island of Oahu. One Japanese tourist shoot pictures rapidly...first of the ships as seen from overhe then he leans to the other side of the plane and shoots pictures of the airfield below them.
Another Japanese tourist hikes through the hills above Pe Harbor. He takes an excellent camera from his picnic bask and shoots pictures. CLOSE - THE PICTURES, being carried down a hallway, into
The courier places the pictures onto the table in front o Yamamoto, Genda, and the other JAPANESE OFFICERS.
Look at the ships -- all grouped. Perfect targets!
And the planes! They are -- what is that American expression? Sitting geese?
Sitting ducks.
How can they be so foolish?
They think no one would be stupid enough to attack them at Pearl Harbor.
Or perhaps they think no one is capable. Look at this... He moves to a diagram displayed on the wall -- a simple display showing water depth and ship displacement.

Pearl Harbor's depth of only forty feet makes them feel safe. A torpedo dropped from an airplane plunges to one hundred feet before it can level off. That is a conventional torpedo. But we have been experimenting. From a stand beside his diagram he takes a set of wooden fins, attached to a circular metallic band.
Wooden fins. We are testing them tomorrow.

Yamamoto and his planners have flown to a quiet Japanese island, sunlit and pleasant. They are gathered on the sho of the island's natural harbor. Wooden targets -- basical huge plank barriers -- are sunk into the water like ships anchor. A squadron of Japanese planes zooms overhead, tak up attack positions.

We have chosen this place because its  depth is exactly the same as Pearl Harbor's. Genda speaks into a field radio. A lone plane drops out o formation and goes into a low-level approach, speeding up dropping its torpedo. BELOW THE SURFACE we see the torpedo as it plunges at two hundred miles an hour into the sunlit sea. With the woode fins the torpedo makes a sharp dip and levels off above t sea floor. ABOVE THE SURFACE the planners see the path of the torped it hits the wooden barrier with a satisfying THUNK. The planners are impressed -- but Yamamoto is not satisfied.
Uncharged torpedoes have different balance.

I have arranged a live fire drill -- with your permission. Yamamoto nods; Genda speaks again into his radio, and ano plane swoops down and drops a torpedo. Genda holds his ha to his ears, causing the others to do the same; even thou they wonder at the need. The torpedo hits the barrier, and the explosion is deafen and of shocking force; the entire barrier is blown to toothpicks.
Of course against a ship the explosion will not be dissipated, and will have more force. The planners, nearly blown off their feet, nod as if they knew that all the time.
The pilots are getting slicked up.
Are you sure they're here?
If Evelyn's here, the rest are here! Red moves up beside him to frown at the mirror. His hair plastered down and parted, his uniform's immaculate.
Looking good, Red.  Shut up. Red moves away, to polish his shoes.
What is it with Red? I've never seen him this way.
He's been like that all day. Hey Danny, you coming?
Nah, I'm gonna stay here. Read. Anthony and Billy look at each other; Danny's in his bunk and he's not reading, just staring at the ceiling.
The nurses are primping to go out; Evelyn is in her unifo getting ready to go back to work.
Now listen, it's hands off Billy. I mean, you can put your hands on him if you want to, but then my hands will break yours.
He was that good?
No, I was.
Creeping through the vegetation, Red leads Anthony and Bi to a spot outside the nurses’ barracks; they can see the girls through the barracks window.
Red, Peeping Tom stuff can get us court- marshaled.
Shhh! Anthony and Billy are baffled, even more so when Red stri into the open, right outside the nurses' window. And then, Red begins to sing.

(singing) Oh...Betty, Betty, Betty, you're the one  for me, Betty, Betty, Betty, Betty, can't you see... Anthony and Billy look at each other, dumbfounded. The nurses move to the open windows. Red's singing is pretty good -- though not that good. But he doesn't stutter when sings.

(singing) I'll be yours for eternity, Betty, Betty, Betty, Betty, Betty! Anthony and Billy are hysterical, trying to keep their laughter hidden. But then they see the effect this is hav on the women -- especially on Betty. She's smitten. Red repeats the verse, really getting into it; when he finishes, Betty runs out and hugs him, as all the nurses applaud. They move off into the darkness, arm and arm. The nurses go back to their primping. Anthony and Billy are changed men. Anthony stands up; Billy's baffled. Anthony moves out and starts singing.
(singing) Oh Sandra...I like you...love you... He's terrible. The nurses pelt him with hairbrushes, curlers, shoes...

Coming out of the blustery skies at the end of another de day, a squadron of Spitfires chirps in for landings. The planes are shot up and battered. Rafe is one of the pilots; the fuselage below his cockpit marked with four swastikas, symbols of his victories. He taxis to a stop, and is met by IAN, a Scottish mechanic, is dismayed at the state of the plane.
Leapin' Jesus!
(climbing down) The struts are loose, the hydraulics are leaking, and the electrical system's shorting out in the cockpit.
Well which of those three ya want fixed?
All of 'em. Rafe starts away, and Ian calls to his back --
If ye'd wanted a bloody Cadillac ya should'a stayed in the bloody States!
And if you don't give me a plane that can handle combat, you better start learning to speak German.
Fook ya!
Learn English, then!
Fook ya dooble! Rafe moves to the barracks; Ian keeps the fueling hose go and moves to help the armorers reload the guns.
Rafe falls down onto his cot, exhausted. The other pilots the same, everybody spent from the day's combat. Then the hear the SIREN. Rafe's out of his bunk, with the others, everybody running.
Bloody Krauts! Night raid!
They race across the runway. Rafe reaches his Spitfire, j as Ian is removing the fueling hose.
I have'na been able ta --
Crank her! Ian gives the prop a spin, and the engine roars to life.
God speed ya, laddie.

It's dark, but there are breaks in the clouds, giving way patches of light from a full moon. The squadron of Spitfi tightens up for battle. Rafe is positioned just right of the squad leader; he se planes breaking out of the dark clouds ahead.
Here they come. The clouds break, revealing a huge attack formation.
Alpha group, on the bombers! Beta group, take the fighters! They peel off, into action.

location: THE AIR BATTLE OVER THE CHANNEL

text: We stay with Rafe as he and the Squad Leader rush side by side at the lead bomber, blasting away with their guns.
The Spitfires’ bullets rip into the pilot and also kill t nose gunner; the bomber dips as the copilot struggles to control.
As he streaks past, Rafe sees the bomber wobble in the ai

We've got him hurt, stay on him! Rafe throws his plane into an ultra-tight, high speed tur right between the tails of the leader German group and th noses of the second. His turn is so tight that the plane flexes with the g-force. Rafe comes out of his turn ahead of the Squad Leader, and races back up through the formation of German bombers, mo above them where their weapons and armaments are the weak He stitches a trail of bullets from tail to nose of the wounded lead bomber; it begins to smoke. The second Spitfire, the Squad Leader's, takes fire from other German bombers, and shears off, heading through the smoke of the plane Rafe has on the ropes.

We've got him going! Rafe does a half-loop and half-spin, to bring him around face the bombers again. This time the g-force of the turn pops an oil line inside Rafe's cockpit; hot, pressurized begins to spray everywhere -- all over Rafe, his controls and worst of all, over the inside of his cockpit glass. He wipes at the oil with his hands and that just smears i  and makes it worse. His wingman sees him veering away from the bombers...and the German fighters moving up to meet him.
McCawley! Get to the clouds! Get into the clouds! RAFE, IN HIS PLANE, is flying blind.

I can't see the clouds! His problems are just beginning; the fluid is dripping do onto his cockpit's corroded electrical wiring; the fluid causes an arc...a spark...and suddenly a fire is spreadin through Rafe's plane. He grabs his fire extinguisher and triggers a cloud that snuffs the fire but fills the entire cockpit with choking smoke; between that and the smeared fluid on his glass, h can't see a thing. And the Messerschmidts are swarming over him. Rafe's wingman dives in, raking the German planes as he passes. Rafe tries to open his cockpit cover to clear the smoke, it's jammed; he pulls out his .45 pistol and BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! He blows out the glass; the smoke clears enough for him to take a breath and try to see. He fights the stick, but the plane won't respond. The Messerschmidts rake him again, bullets riddling his engine.

Get out of there, McCawley! Get out of there! Rafe's plane descends, ever faster, passing through cloud then clear air again. The Squad Leader tries to chase and cover him, but Rafe's dropping fast, and still isn't out the plane as the Germans dive on him again, firing. Rafe's Spitfire hits the broken fog over the water -- the Squad Leader loses sight of it for a moment -- and then t plane hits, splashing and exploding all at once. The Squad Leader winces, and ducks into the clouds as he reports on his radio...
McCawley down. No ‘chute.

The sailors have assembled on deck for the ship's heavywe championship fight, a contest made more interesting to th sailors because one of the combatants is white and the ot is black. The battle is more toughness than technique. The guys throwing haymakers and shoving each other around the rope area, as their shipmates cheer and make wild bets. The wh guy digs a punch deep into the black guy's ribs, and the black guy slams a double left hook into the white guy's belly, making him back up and say --

You hit hard -- for a cook. The black guy rushes the white guy, only to catch a right cross that wobbles his knees and makes him stagger, with fresh cut over his right eye. The white guy now rushes in and the black guy (his name is DORIE MILLER) throws an up cut that drops his opponent like a sack of rocks. The sailors cheer wildly. Dorie steps back, and rubs his glove across his brow. It's really bleeding now.
Evelyn is returning from church with six of her nurse friends. It's very quiet on a Sunday morning, almost nobo at the base; they walk along the path.
Let's get into civvies and find a bar.
Right after church?
You've gotta sin some, to get forgiveness. Come with us, Evelyn. You need some sin.
I've got to write some requisitions. We're undersupplied with morphine.
Morphine? We've been here a month and nobody's had worse than a sunburn. Evelyn smiles softly and walks toward the base hospital.
I wish she could forget him.
You don't forget love, Honey. Not ever.
Evelyn approaches the hospital and finds the black boxer peering in the window. He's in a T-shirt and navy pants.
Can I help you, sailor? As Dorie turns, she sees the cut on his head, closed only with a band-aid; it's dripping blood down his T-shirt.
"Scuse me, ‘Mam. All the ship's doctors is golfing, and I couldn't find nobody to look at this.
Our doctor's gone too.
Sorry to trouble you.
Wait, let me look at that... You better come in here.
Miller is sitting on a stool; Evelyn bathes the wound.
How'd you get this?
Boxin'.
Win?
Yes'm. He says it without pride. She puts down the basin.
What's your name?
Dorie Miller, ‘Mam.
I'm Evelyn. And I'm just a nurse. But I'm not playing golf, and that cut needs sewing, or else it's gonna make a big lumpy scar. Whatta ya say?
Evelyn clips the ends of her carefully applied stitches; Dorie's eyes are rolled up as if he could watch from insi his skull.
How often you fight like this?
Every other Sunday. I'm heavyweight champion of the West Virginia.
What do you get for winning?
Respect. She hands him a mirror. He studies her work.
No doctor would'a give me that good. She walks him to the door.
Thank you, ‘Mam.
Tell me something, Dorie. A man as big as you -- and smart too, you knew where to come when your ship couldn't help -- do you still have to fight with your fists to get respect?

I left my Mama and joined the Navy to be aman. They made me a cook -- and not even that, really -- I clean up after the other sailors eat. I shine the officer's shoes. In two years, they've never even let me fire a gun. Now Evelyn understands.
You take care, Dorie.
You too, 'Mam.

Dorie walks away, down the path between the palm trees. S watches him go, and then is transfixed by someone else  coming, silhouetted by the light of the setting sun. She can't make out his face, but he's wearing a pilot's dress uniform, and coming to her right out of the warm orange sunset that she has stared at so many times. Her heart sl against her ribs; she takes a few steps forward.
...-Rafe... She moves toward him, and he draws near her, walking slow And then she sees his face... It's Danny. His face as sad as death itself. And even before he tells her, she knows.
Lieutenant... I'm Danny Walker. I'm Rafe McCawley's best friend.
Were. Isn't that what you mean? Were. Because he's dead, isn't he? And that's why you've come.
Evelyn and Danny sit on the bench, with a sweeping view o the harbor and the lights winking on all around it as the settles beyond the horizon. Evelyn is stoic, numb; Danny the one who is struggling.
Before Rafe left, he asked me to be the one to tell you, if it happened.
He told me about you. That he had no other friend like you.

Rafe's folks had a crop dusting business, owned their own planes. Real straight, frugal. My father was the town drunk. Went to sleep one night on the railroad tracks and was still there when the Dawn Express came along. Rafe and I were the only ones at the funeral. He took me back to his house, and I never left.
You were more like brothers.
I taught him to drink beer. He taught me how to fly.
He said you're the only one he ever saw who was better in the air than him.
...He said that? Evelyn nods, still staring away from Danny. This pierces Danny; he looks away, struggling not to let the emotions him completely under.

Look, uh...Rafe's dad...he wrote me with the news, and it took me a couple of days to work up the guts to come here and tell you. I'm not as brave as Rafe, or as noble. But if there's anything I can ever do to help -- you let me know, okay? She stares into the distance. He stands and puts his hand top of hers, as much for his comfort as for hers.

I understand why Rafe loved you. You're as strong as he was. Since she's still not looking at him, he starts to move a When he reaches the turn in the path, he looks back, and her figure in the gathering darkness. She's begun to brea down; and as he watches, her whole body starts convulsing and she doubles up in shattering grief. Danny can't just stand there; he moves back to her, and p a hand on her shoulder. He sits beside her again, and suddenly she turns to him and sobs upon him. Danny wraps gently in his arms, and then he breaks down, having found first place he can truly grieve.

The Japanese have constructed a replica of Pearl Harbor o their practice island; erecting new target barriers and silhouettes of the various ships anchored at Pearl. Strea of Japanese planes skim overhead in practice bombing runs dropping dummy torpedoes and bombs. From a control platfo erected on the beach, Yamamoto and Genda oversee it all.
Everything real except the fact that no one is shooting back at us.
If we achieve surprise, they will offer little resistance.

Set up teams of radio operators to send  out messages the Americans will intercept, concerning every potential American target in the Pacific. Include Hawaii -- the clutter will be more confusing that way.
Brilliant, Admiral.
A brilliant man would find a way not to fight a war. He looks out at the planes roaring into his practice harb at top speed...
Roosevelt's valet leans over him. Roosevelt wakes; beside the valet is a Presidential AIDE.
Mr. President, we've received a message from the Argentinian ambassador to Japan. His sources tell him the Japanese are assembling their fleet to attack us.
We're picking up warnings for every American base in the Pacific. Does this ambassador know the target?
Not for sure. But he thinks it's Pearl Harbor.
Tell the Pentagon. The Aide leaves quickly and Roosevelt starts to get out o bed; his valet comes to help him.
No, George, I need the practice, in case there's a fire. Roosevelt drags himself out of bed, crawling toward the bathroom, his powerful arms dragging his lifeless legs.
ADMIRALS and other OFFICERS are gathered around a giant m of the Pacific.
The attack seems inevitable. The  question is where? The way to answer that question is to ask: if we were the Japanese, how would we do it? He nods to a VICE ADMIRAL, who stands over the map.

Between America and the Far East are the sea lanes where the winds and the currents make the best route for shipping. Far above is the northern route, between Canada and Russia. Between these two is something they call the Vacant Sea. If I were the Japs, I'd send a task force there. You could hide the entire land mass of Asia in the Vacant Sea, and nobody would know.
So they pop out and attack where?
That's the problem, Admiral. They could hit anywhere they want. Nobody has any solution.

A huge Japanese fleet steams toward Hawaii. It is an awes sight. Carriers, battleships, destroyers, and entire batt group, traveling under complete radio silence, their hull power through the waves. On the lower decks of the carrie are hundreds of planes -- fighters and bombers.
The American ships are lined up at anchor, calm, placid.
The sailors and soldiers bask in the sun, play volleyball The aircraft carrier Lexington steams past toward the har entrance.
Where's the Lexington going?
Out on maneuvers, like the Enterprise.
Men in military haircuts -- officers -- stroll the golf courses, enjoying themselves.
The DENTIST, an ethnic Japanese, is working on a patient his mouth agape. The DENTIST ASSISTANT intrudes.
Dr. Takanawa, you have a call from Tokyo.
Please excuse me. Just relax. Leaving his patient with a mouth full of instruments, the Dentist moves to his outer office, which looks directly o over Pearl Harbor. He speaks in Japanese.
Takanawa... Yes?... He seems confused by the call, but he responds by looking over the harbor, then saying into the receiver --
Yes, they are all...no wait, I see the big one moving. The one that's flat on top, what do they call it?...
Some tired Army Intelligence types -- A LISTENER, a TRACK and an INTELLIGENCE SUPERVISOR, are sitting at a bank of phones. The LISTENER is a Japanese-American.
Here's something, over the line from Tokyo. He switches on the recording equipment and looks to the TRACER, sitting at a battery of equipment.
It's connected to a local dentist. His office is beside Pearl Harbor.
This dentist, is he a spy?
Sounds too innocent. His accent is from the old country. Somebody official- sounding calls, he thinks it's discourteous not to respond.
Admiral Kimmel is settling into the barber chair when his AIDE enters and nods for the barber to move a few paces a so that he can speak privately.
Sir, we just had an intelligence intercept. Someone from Tokyo called a local dentist whose office looks over Pearl. They wanted to know the exact location of the ships.
Someone from Tokyo asks a dentist how the ships are sitting... What are we supposed to do about that?
I...don't know, Sir. But it just seemed significant.
Have intelligence keep monitoring him. The Admiral sinks back into the chair.

A young amateur PHOTOGRAPHER, about 16, wearing a hat wit "PICTURES OF PARADISE" printed on it's crown is ready to a shot of Evelyn and her nurse friends having a picnic lu on the lawn outside the hospital.
Closer, ladies! Closer! Now smile!... Great! Next week I'll show you a print and you can order your Pictures of Paradise! He hustles off. Betty hands out picnic baskets.
Barbara, here's yours...and Evelyn, here you are. Evelyn opens her basket, and finds a lei of Hawaiian flow stuffed in the top. Betty scoots over and puts the flower around Evelyn's neck.

It's been a month and you haven't smiled. We just want you to know we love you. Evelyn's touched -- but before she can react two P-40's z out of the skies, wings clipping the tops of the palm tre as they blast over head.
Danny and Anthony are the pilots; as they pull up and awa they pass over some officers on the golf course, scaring  shit out of them as they putt.
The nurses have sprawled to the ground; now even Evelyn i smiling.
What is it with nurses and pilots?

Evelyn walks out of the hospital. She's still wearing her lei. The sun is going down in a spectacular sunset. She stares at the orange glow at the edge of the world. S breathes in the sea air, and tries to breathe out the sadness. The water of the harbor laps close to where she stands, the sunset polishing its surface. She takes the lei from her neck, plucks a single flower, holds it like the rose Rafe once gave her. Then she tosse the rest of the lei into the ocean and watches it float a as the sun sinks behind the horizon.
Evelyn finds her purse, and tucks the flower into it. She alone in the hospital, everyone else has gone; she turns mind toward work, something to lose herself in.
Danny is walking toward the barracks when a COLONEL hoppi mad, confronts him.
You're Walker, right?
Yes Sir.
That was a nice little stunt you pulled, buzzing the base.
You liked that?
Oh yeah. I liked it so much I'm cutting you out of the squadron.
Sir?
I don't buy that hot dog shit. So you and your buddies are gonna transfer your planes up to Haleiwa.
Hale-what?
You'll love it. No base, no bars, just lots of sun and aircraft maintenance.
Sir, I --
Too late for apologies, Walker.
I wasn't gonna apologize, Sir. I was just gonna say it was worth it to feel like a real pilot again, even if it was only for five seconds. The Colonel glares at him and stalks away.
Danny and Evelyn are having coffee at the base canteen.
How's everything?
We got some soldiers in traction from a jeep accident, but it's quiet. Except for the occasional fighter plane buzzing us.

That might not have been such a good idea. They're making us fly out of a half-paved airfield. The real punishment is that I won't be back to the barracks till it's too late for dinner or coffee. So I guess it's goodbye for awhile.
I was just thinking that war is a series of goodbyes. Do you think that's why we're meeting. To help us say goodbye to Rafe?

I swore not to talk about him tonight, but there's all this stuff I think I ought to tell you, that he didn't get a chance to. Rafe was...he was lonely. He  had such high expectations of himself that he always felt empty. The week he met you he told me he felt his heart had always lived in winter, and for the first time in his life he has seen the spring. He's been lost in his own thoughts of Rafe; now he notice the tears welling up in her eyes.
Sorry.
He told me he didn't want to leave me with regret. Now that's all I have.
Hey, have you seen Pearl Harbor at night?
Well...sure.
From the air?
A P-40 takes off from the remote airfield, lit only by th full moon.

Evelyn sits on Danny's lap, like Rafe sat in his Daddy's years before. Danny flies easily, the cockpit open, his a slipped under hers. The sky above them is startlingly clear; a billion stars dancing around a full moon.
So beautiful!

Hang on. He spins the plane in an easy half turn, inverting their heads above Pearl Harbor, gorgeous in the moonlight, the battleships aglow, the moon reflected in the peaceful wat embraced by the island of Oahu.
The P-40 soars easily in and settles to earth. Danny shut down the engine. Danny carefully removes the harness arou her. She looks overhead. The stars are still bright above them.
I didn't realize until tonight that I've stopped wanting to live. She turns in his lap, and looks at him. Their eyes connec Tentatively, almost reluctantly, they kiss.

The POV of someone moving through the gathering darkness approaches the hospital. The lights from within the hospital, and the pristine whi beds beneath those lights, give the place a kind of glow, where Evelyn moves alone and beautiful, like a ballerina giant's jewel box. Now we see the shoulders of the figure, from behind, and tell that it is a man in uniform, but at first we can't t who. He's standing dead still, transfixed in watching Eve through the windows.

Evelyn moves to her desk, and sits down. She looks at the calender turning back to October, where she wrote on the square of October 22, "Order supplies" -- she counts the weeks from then to today, December 6.

We see the full figure of the man watching her. And now w see his face. It is Rafe. His left hand is bandaged, but he is very much alive -- though seeing Evelyn has taken his breath, and even seems have robbed him of the power to move. His eyes pick up ev detail of her -- her face...her hands. And as Rafe watches Evelyn, he has the SUDDEN JOLTS OF SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACKS...punctuated by fragments of the le she wrote to him, and INTERCUT with Rafe in the present, watching Evelyn.

Dearest Rafe -- IN SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACK, RAFE'S SPITFIRE, crippled and trailing smoke, passing through a patch of cloud as Rafe hurls himself from the cockpit and jerks the ripcord of h chute. IN THE PRESENT...Rafe's face winces with the memory, and rivets his eyes on Evelyn, as if to force himself to know that this moment is real. SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACK...RAFE LANDS IN THE WATER, and the s  of its coldness travels up his body faster than his body sinks into the water. He's cloaked in the fog; his parachute, pushed by the wind, is pulling him along face down. He fights with the straps, flips himself over, and pulls the release... But he's still in desperate trouble; in his flying clothe his heavy leather jacket soaking with sea-water, he's goi down; his body sinks beneath the surface.

...Every sunset... IN THE PRESENT, Rafe's chest trembles... Is it from the memory of the frozen water, from the emotion of seeing Ev again -- or both? SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACKS -- Below the surface of the North S Rafe's body drifts, but he fights his way back up...he ki off his shoes, sheds the jacket, strips off his pants and starts tying the cuffs into knots. Then, in a CUT, he is floating in the water, his pants tu into a makeshift life preserver, his body shaking convulsively from the cold. Then in another CUT we see him after he's been in the wat for so long that his body no longer trembles; he's lost consciousness. He has no strength, no will to live... His face settles into the water...his body slips from his preserver, and drifts beneath the surface...

...gather it's heat into my heart, and send it to you... IN FLASHBACK, Rafe beneath the surface... His eyes come o From his POV beneath the water, he sees something above t surface. It's only in his mind, but that makes it no less real...an orange glow, the warmth of the sunset, and her above the surface... His limbs come to life, and he fight his way up, breaking the surface. The whole sea around hi is dark and empty, but he grabs his makeshift preserver a holds on for dear life...and for Evelyn. IN THE PRESENT Rafe stares through the window, at Evelyn, he can't go in. He backs away from the window.
A Japanese-American MESSAGE BOY parks his motorbike outsi and enters the barracks.
Daniel Walker?... Danny rises from his bunk and accepts the telegram. As th message boy leaves, Danny reads... The news he learns st him...
Rafe is still lost in thought. He hears steps running up and sees Danny -- who spots him at the same moment.
Rafe!
Evelyn puts away the calender.

Rafe is sitting at the bench, his head down. ANGLE - Evelyn on the path; she sees someone on the bench his form hauntingly familiar. He hears her, and looks up. It's Rafe. From Evelyn's POV, the whole world spins. She faints. Rafe jumps to catch her before she slams to the ground. H gathers her into his arms, and she looks up into his face He's real, very real.
Evelyn. She's trembling, shaking. He lifts her to her feet, and moves her to the bench.
I sent telegrams, I guess the military traffic held them up.
Why were you sitting here, instead of...
I saw you, I couldn't go in, I...just stood there wondering if you knew. You looked...sad, and I had to sit down a minute.
How did you?...

...Survive? I jumped in a patch of fog, and nobody could see me. I hit the water hard. And it was so...cold. He looks toward the horizon, when the last light of day f  to black. There's something he thinks about saying, and doesn't. Then...

I don't know how long I was in the water. A Norwegian freighter picked me up. They were headed to Spain. They docked in La Rota, right beside a German ship, and told me to stay hidden below. I was afraid they'd turn me in, so I stole some clothes, jumped ship, and found a church, where the priest contacted the resistance, and got me on a freighter to New York. He looks at her, then looks down again.

I called my folks, then Colonel Doolittle. The Colonel sent a man to pick me up. They wanted to debrief me. I told the Colonel I needed to see somebody first, and he had a supply flight heading out in an hour. (beat) I've done a lot of talking. You haven't said anything.
I'm just...so amazed, so glad to know that you're okay. You are okay, aren't you?
Nothing that won't heal. I guess. At these words, she looks at him for a long, long moment.
It's been...so different, being so sure you were dead.
I'm so sorry for what you must've gone through, but I'm back. He sees the troubled look on her face.
Maybe I've assumed too much. Has something changed? (beat) I'm afraid to ask what. And I'm afraid not to. (beat) Have you fallen in love?  She nods; she can't even say it. Rafe's dying inside.
It's all right. Danny always said I see things with my emotions instead of my eyes.
It's not your fault, Rafe. The letter I wrote you, they --
Don't worry about that. Guys away from home, lonely, good-hearted women try to cheer them up.
It's not that I didn't mean everything I wrote. It's just that -- I thought you were dead. And now -- Danny runs up, through the darkness.

You're alive! Rafe and Danny stare at each other; Danny hesitates, look from Rafe to Evelyn, wondering what they've said. Then Ra looks at Evelyn, and picks up the look on her face. In th moment he puts it all together.
Aw, God. Oh my God. Danny's speechless, and for a moment Evelyn is too.
Rafe -- He puts up a hand, to silence her, and walks away suddenl Evelyn and Danny are left frozen.
Rafe stares out at the harbor, seeing nothing. As he stan there alone and shattered, he has one more

Rafe is in the water of the North Sea; he seems dead, but makeshift preserver is keeping his face above the surface Something slides through the water and stops beside him; a dinghy, and behind it is a trawler. Hands grab Rafe and drag him onto the dinghy... In a QUICK CUT, Rafe's body is laid out on the deck of th  trawler. The crewmen think he's dead. His body is stiff, his lips white; and they say so, in Norwegian... But one of the other crewmen notices a quiver in his eyel then quickly covers Rafe with his on wool peacoat and pre back an eyelid to see his pupils. Rafe's white lips move. The crewmen realize he's trying to say something. And Rafe does utter something, barely audible; something Norwegian crewmen don't understand.
Evelyn... IN THE PRESENT Rafe struggles to bury that memory so far he'll never feel it again.
Danny escorts Evelyn back to her quarters.
Don't worry. I'll find him. He hugs her; their embrace earnest yet tingled with guilt and Danny leave quickly. Betty steps out of the nurses’ quarters and hands Evelyn a telegram.

This came while you were gone. Evelyn knows it's the telegram from Rafe, to tell her he' alive. Without opening it, she begins to cry, and hurries away from the barracks so the other nurses won't see.

Danny crosses the tarmac toward the clustered P-40's. He spots what he's looking for. Sitting in the cockpit of on of the P-40's is Rafe. Rafe won't look at him. Danny clim up on the wing, and sits down there.
You'd always go sit in a plane whenever you were upset.
Upset? Why should I be upset?
Let's go get a drink. Unless you're scared to talk about it. CLOSE - A Mai-Tai volcano clunks onto a table.
Drink up. Then we'll talk. Rafe takes the challenge, and takes a long pull on one of straws. Red, Anthony, Billy, and several others enter the bar.
Rafe?! They rush the table...
They're all drinking, and the whole bar is rocking. Rafe uses glasses to show his buddies tactics.

They'll go under you because their planes are faster, then they run so you can't catch 'em. But then they'll come around and take you from behind -- like some Americans will. The last words bring the group to silence. The other guys drift away, to give them room.
Sorry.
Why be sorry? That's what you feel, it's better to come out with it.
I didn't mean it.
Sure you did. So come on. Say what you think.
Waitress! Four beers!
You don't wanna put beer over mai-tai.
If you can't keep up, don't drink yours. The waitress delivers four bottles to the table. Rafe tak a slow sip, then stares at Danny.
We gotta face some facts here.
What facts are those?
I understand how it could happen. I know why any guy would love her. And I can't blame you that it happened. You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.
I was grieving too.
Yeah, right. Anyway, you didn't know.
So what are you saying?
I'm saying now you do know. So it's time for you to fuck off.
You left her. How's that for a fact?
How's this for a fact? I loved her first. Danny takes a long pull of beer, and Rafe does the same.
You know, you're a lousy drinker. Drinking's supposed to make men feel bigger. It only makes you stupid. And weak. Rafe nods thoughtfully, and sets down his beer.
How's this? BAM! He knocks Danny out of the chair, flat on his ass. Danny backhands the blood from the corner of his mouth.

You want it, you got it. He kicks Rafe in the back of the knee, then mule kicks hi the chest as he goes down, and the fight is on. The bar's bouncer, a big Samoan, moves over to break them -- but Anthony steps in his way.

Let ‘em fight, they need it. The bouncer tosses Anthony aside, but before he can move to interrupt the fight, Red breaks a lava volcano of Mai- over the bouncer's skull. The bartender picks up the phon to call the M.P.'s. Rafe and Danny are exchanging punches in the middle of th room. Sailors sitting at the bar have swung around on the stools to watch the action. The other pilots are wincing with the punches their friends exchange, and bobbing and weaving as if in the fight themselves. A SAILOR tapes Bil

Is this a private fight or can anybody jump in? Billy hits him. The whole bar erupts. Rafe and Danny are really having at it, fueled by so much emotion that nothing hurts. They're on the floor now, try to rip each other apart. They struggle to their feet and Rafe manages to knee Danny in the balls. Danny doubles ov in pain.

That hurt? I didn't think you had any balls. Without looking up, Danny lunges at Rafe, tackling him ar the waist, driving him at the wall. But they don't hit the wall; they tumble through the back window of the bar -- not covered in glass, but fronds and wood -- and out into the back alley. They're lying there in the debris when they see the M.P. jeeps coming. They drag each other to their feet, and run away.
The Japanese task force rumbles through the night, the bo of the great ships blasting through the crashing waves.
Yamamoto's flagship. The clock reaches midnight, and a sailor tears off it's calender. It's December 7, 1941.
The submarines will be reaching the harbor soon. I hope they don't set off the alarm too soon.
An American destroyer, the SELFRIDGE, leads a squadron of destroyers on patrol, near the entrance of Pearl Harbor.  LOOKOUTS on the bridge think they spot something.
The WATCH OFFICER listens to a report on his headset and turns to the CAPTAIN.
Captain, lookouts report a sighting, two points off the starboard beam. The sonar operator looks up and nods.
How big?
.»..I've lost it.
Probably a blackfish. I've seen them look like subs.
Another destroyer, the RALPH TALBOT, cruises behind the Selfridge. On it's bridge, the DUTY OFFICER speaks to the CAPTAIN.

Sir, Selfridge reports a contact, then lost it. Now our sonar reports the contact. The Captain looks toward the Selfridge, then trains his binoculars on the water were the Duty Officer points. He sees something dark and black slipping along beneath the surface. He gets onto his intercom.
Radio room! Raise the Selfridge. Tell the Squadron Commander we have spotted a sub and request permission to depth charge. He looks again at the black shape, passing a few hundred yards from them.
We're five miles from Pearl Harbor and it's moving in from the open sea. Prepare to move to attack speed. The INTERCOM comes alive.
Sir, the Squadron Commander on Selfridge  denies permission.
What?

Denies, Sir. He says it's a blackfish. The Captain chokes back his frustration and shuts down th intercom -- but then he says to the Duty Officer, as they watch the shape disappear toward Pearl Harbor...
If it's a blackfish, it has a motorboat up it's ass!

Danny has pulled his Buick convertible off the road; Rafe bent over, his head out of frame; he's throwing up. Danny banged up from the fight and still drunk himself; he wait beside Rafe, who chokes out between heaves --
How come you're not pukin'?

I guess I'm used to it. I've felt like throwing up every minute since you got back. Rafe straightens up, but the waves of sickness come back him and he bends over again. Danny looks at his friend, a the pain is written on Danny's face.
Don't blame her, Rafe. It's not like you're thinking.
(between heaves) Fuck you.
She loves you. I know that. And part of what she loves in me is how much of you she sees in me. Rafe doesn't seem to be listening; but Danny knows he is.

We were both torn up. I started dropping by to see her, because we understood what each other felt. We'd have coffee and try not to talk about you, but we always would. Rafe stands to face Danny; this is hard for Danny to say

She said I was so much like you. I said, No, I'm not. I'm like I am because of you, but I'm not you, not as good as you. Everybody else saw me as a loser with a big chip on his shoulder. But you saw the better part of me, the part of me that could be like you, and changed me. You made me who I am.

How sweet. Is that when you put the move on her? Danny slams his fist into Rafe's sick gut. Rafe doubles o again, coughing, nothing left in his belly to come up. Rafe stand slowly, nodding as if he knows the punch was w he deserved. Danny's about to apologize when once more Ra knees him in the balls. Danny folds up, drops to his knees, and starts to retch.
That's better. Rafe crawls into the back seat of the car and passes out, Danny still collapsed at the side of the road.
The Japanese task force storms on.
IN THE PREP DECKS, the planes are being armed with bombs torpedoes. IN THE PILOTS' QUARTERS, the pilots individually sit befo personal shrines, saying private prayers, writing letters
The planes are brought up on the elevators; deck crewmen start rolling them into position.

location: UNDER THE SURFACE OF THE PACIFIC

text: A Japanese submarine with a midget sub attached to its hu runs silently toward Pearl Harbor.
The periscope of the submarine breaks the surface.
The sub commander looks through the periscope and sees th lights of Oahu far in the distance.
Prepare to launch midget sub.

location: BUNK AREA OF SUB, BETWEEN TORPEDOES

text: The sailor who will drive the midget sub completes his ceremonial sponge bath, and places a handwritten letter o his personal shrine.
My revered father, I go now to fulfill my mission and my destiny.

location: THE LAUNCH OF THE MIDGET SUB

text: We see the sub surface, and the sailor exit the main hatc the big sub, then force himself through the tiny hatch of midget sub.

I hope it is a destiny that will bring honor to our family, and if it requires my life I will sacrifice it gladly, if you can think of me and my hope to be a good servant of our nation, and a worthy son. With love and devotion, Kazuyoshi.
A single scout plane launches into the air.
The plane climbs to a high altitude, toward the dawn and Pearl Harbor.
The Japanese carriers turn into the wind and raise combat pennants. A color guard raises the Japanese flag as the d crew stand at attention, seeing the rising-sun flag snap potently in the wind.

The first wave of Japanese planes begins to launch. It is stirring sight for the Japanese; the pilots waiting in th cockpits, the officers watching from the bridge, the seam on the flight deck. The first plane taxis along the flight deck and lifts int the sky. The seamen cheer and wave their caps.
The American destroyer WARD cuts through the water, movin back into port after a night patrol. It's CAPTAIN is on t bridge, and its lookouts are still scanning the waters.
Captain, do you see that, in our wake? The Captain raises his binoculars and looks out behind th ship. He sees something small and black there.
That's a conning tower.
Could it be one of ours?
He's trying to follow us through the sub nets, into the harbor. Sink the son of a bitch.
The deck gun barks, aimed toward the conning tower of the Japanese sub in the distance. The first shot sails direct over the tower, missing.
The Japanese sub commander sees, through his periscope, t flame erupt on the Ward's deck; he's being fired upon. He snaps orders --
Dive! Dive!
The gunners snap in another shell and fire again. It's a direct hit, the sub is ripped apart, it rolls over.
The Captain watches the sub sinking and snaps an order.
Fleet command, from destroyer Ward. Have fired upon and sunk enemy submarine seeking to enter Pearl Harbor.
There are two guys left in the room, yawning over their radar equipment. The Officer, ELLIS, checks his watch; it a few minutes after seven a.m.
Time to shut her down. That was a good first session. You'll get the hang of this new radar soon.
