Thank you, Sir. Hey...what's this? His screen shows a huge cloud of blips, heading toward th
I've never seen anything like that before. He gets on the telephone.
The phone rings and an officer answers.
Watch command... Coming from which direction?... Hold on. He covers the phone and tells his commander --
Radar station has picked up a cloud of blips, coming in from the northeast. He switches on the radio, and tunes it to KGMB; hearing t Hawaiian music reassures him something...
KGMB is on early. That means we've got a flight of B-17's coming in from the mainland, they use the radio music for a homing beacon.
Dismayed, Ellis listens to the response from the headquarters.
All right, Sir. (he hangs up) They say don't worry about it. He and the private look again at the cloud of blips -- growing ever larger, and moving in fast.
The Japanese formations are streaking through the sky.

The Japanese bombers, with three-man crews, are listening the Hawaiian music of the radio station, using it for the homing beacon. They look out and see the sunrise -- it's beautiful, and resembles the Japanese flag.
The Japanese scout plane is high in the air. It radios --
Harbor quiet. Ships in place. Carriers gone.
Yamamoto is handed this message.
We have achieved surprise, but their carriers are not in port. I don't like this.
We have a fighter screen up, in case we are attacked, Admiral.
We must go ahead. This is our moment.
The Admiral, dressed in his golf clothes, is leaving his when a naval LIEUTENANT appears at his door.
Admiral, one of our destroyers reports sinking a sub on its way into Pearl.
Relay that to Washington...and cancel my golf game.
Kimmel enters his office, and is handed the latest dispatches.
Any response from Washington?
Nothing, Sir.
A telegram, addressed to Admiral Kimmel, lands in the regular, not urgent, dispatch box. The messenger handles promptly, hopping on his motorbike to deliver it.
The Japanese planes increase throttle and nose down, divi toward the surface, hurtling into attack mode.
The harbor lies quiet. It's a sleepy Sunday morning. Children are playing, officers are stepping from their ho in their shorts to get the morning paper...

Hawaiian Boy Scouts are hiking on a side of one of the mountains overlooking Pearl. Suddenly booming over the mountain, barely ten feet above summit, comes a stream of planes. The boys are awed. What is this?

QUICK INTERCUTS - Between the approach of the Japanese planes, and sleepy Pearl Harbor... -- The planes, in formation, their propellers spinning, t engines throbbing... -- Pearl Harbor, with the ships silent, their engines col their anchors steady on the harbor bottom. -- The Japanese submarines heading in. -- The American destroyers docking, instead of going out search for them. -- Another formation of Japanese bombers climbing high, i attack position. -- The Japanese torpedo planes dropping down to the level the ocean, their engines beginning to scream. -- The American planes bunched on the airfields. -- ON THE JAPANESE CARRIERS, Yamamoto and his staff huddl tensely, over their battle maps. ON THE JAPANESE CARRIER DECKS, the second wave of planes being brought up and loaded with munitions...the Japanese  flag snaps tautly in the wind... ON THE GOLD COURSE NEAR PEARL HARBOR, American officers a laughing on the putting green near the club house, where American flag droops from the flag pole, limply at peace. -- The Japanese planes roaring down just over the wave to of Pearl Harbor itself. -- Children playing in the early morning sun, looking up they see the planes flash by. The children look -- they've never seen this many, flying this low...but they are not alarmed, only curious. The images come faster and faster, the collision of Japan determination and American's innocence...
Two sailors are standing on the deck, sharing a smoke, looking out over the quiet harbor. One of them sees the first few planes streaking in.
Look at that.
It's the Army again, practicing on us. Something drops from the lead plane and splashes easily i the water; the plane banks away.
Practice torpedoes. A white streak runs through the water at them.

Now listen, you'll hear a little thud when it hits the side of the ship. They watch it rush at them...then, a MASSIVE EXPLOSION! I throws up a fifty foot wall of water, hurling the sailors everything else on the deck into the sea.

-- The first wave of planes drop more torpedoes; they plu BENEATH THE SURFACE, their wooden fins working perfectly, the torpedoes speeding to their targets... We see their AWESOME BLASTS against the anchored ships as torpedoes hit home. -- The Japanese LOW ALTITUDE BOMBERS come in; some drop t bombs directly into the ships; some skip their bombs across the water, the bombs glancing off the surface and  then slamming the sides of battleships with tremendous explosions. -- INSIDE THE SHIPS, sleeping sailors are thrown from the bunks; those already awakened run for their battle stations, and try to make it up to the deck; but there's no escape there, as... -- Zero fighter planes strafe the ships, raking the decks killing sailors with MACHINE GUN FIRE.

Fire and smoke are turning everything into chaos. some sailors rush to man the guns, they find the ammo boxes locked. Under the bombing and strafing, they find a wrench and st pounding on the lock, trying to break open the ammo box. Then they break open the lock -- and find the ammo box em
Shit! I'll get some ammo! He runs for the ladders, and is shot down before he gets there.
The dive bombers scream in.
Bombs are hitting the deck. Sailors are blown into the ai and out into the oily water. Nearby ships are catching fi the flames spread out onto the oily water itself.

location: BELOW DECKS OF THE WEST VIRGINIA

text: Dorie Miller, the boxing champion/kitchen helper, is work picking up the breakfast trays when he feels the ship shudder. The intercom comes alive --

Battle stations! Battle stations! This is not a drill! Men run to the ladders, and the shaking of the ship from bomb blast tosses them off; Dorie's at the foot of the la when men fall back on top of him.
The Captain of the ship has reached the command bridge, w most of his staff is lying wounded from a bomb blast.

Stay calm! Find your positions. Medics, get the wounded to sick bay! Load and -- MORE TORPEDOES and BOMBS blast into the ship. A big chunk shrapnel tears into the Captain and rips his stomach open The medics he was just directing to other men now run to as the men they were going to help have been blown apart.

Sailors run up from below and are gunned down and blasted down before they can reach their weapons. Dorie Miller emerges from below decks and sees the carnag the confusion. A bloody OFFICER grabs him.
Boy! We need stretcher bearers on the bridge! Dorie runs into the fire and smoke, toward the bridge.
Dorie arrives to see the medics crouched over the disemboweled Captain, who is still giving orders.
Radio for air cover. Organize the other medics. Initiate fire control. Dorie helps the medic lift the Captain to take him below.

location: BELOW DECKS OF THE WEST VIRGINIA

text: Dorie carries the Captain down the ladder by himself, usi one arm to climb and one to hold the Captain like a child teddy bear. When they reach the bottom the pain has grown too much for the Captain; he know's he's dying.
Put me down here. Dorie puts him down; the medic jumps down the ladder and reaches the Captain, who tells him --
Find my executive officer and tell him he's in command. Tell him to fire the boilers and... He trembles in death throes...

Make sure the gunners have enough ammuni --  He's dead. The Medic runs toward the ladder, reaches the hatch, and is blasted back to the bottom by an explosion overhead. Dorie runs for the ladder, and climbs out into hell.

Dorie emerges into even greater carnage and confusion. A sailor, his body on fire, runs past and leaps into the oi water -- but it is in flames too. Then Dorie sees it: an unmanned anti-aircraft gun. He run to it, through the strafing. The gun already has a belt of ammo in it -- apparently lo by the gunner who lies beside it with his chest shot open Dorie swings the business end of the gun toward the Zeros coming in out of the smoke, and he begins to fire. The Zeros keep coming and he keeps firing; nothing on ear will knock him from that gun.
Evelyn is up, dressed; her roommates are just stirring.
Evelyn has stepped to the door when she hears a distant rumble and looks across the harbor to see smoke rising, s taking hits.
Oh my God... EVERYBODY TO THE HOSPITAL! As she runs, Japanese planes are coming toward the base.

location: THE MESS HALL AT HICKAM FIELD

text: The men were sitting down to breakfast, but the machine g bullets tearing up the outer walls have them clogging the doors, and it's so clogged they can't all get out. A steel bomb crashes through the roof and slams through t room, taking out tables and chairs before bouncing off th wall and coming to a stop. TWO SOLDIERS, trapped within the mess hall, see it stop without detonating. They are bug-eyed, hearts stopped.
Dud. The bomb detonated, blowing everything to bloody dust.
Evelyn reaches the hospital first and runs to the cabine withdrawing supplies. Barbara and Sandra appear at the far door, both terrified
Get everything out! Bandages, sutures -- oh God, the men in traction... Come with me! She races into the hallway, the other two following.
Four men from a jeep accident are lying in traction, thei casted limbs roped in the air. Evelyn runs in, grabbing a razor blade from the medical cabinet -- and telling Barba and Sandra.

Cut them down, and take cover!! Hurry! Bombs are falling outside, on the airfield this wing of t hospital faces. Evelyn slices the traction ropes of a man with both legs broken; ignoring his groans, she rolls him of the bed and covers him with the mattress. The other nurses follow her lead. The bombs are coming toward the hospital ward; Evelyn finishes with the fourth man and co him and herself with the mattress, just as a bomb craters outside the window. The nurses and patients look up after the explosions have passed; there's a chunk of smoking shrapnel lying on the springs of the bunk where the last man had been lying.

The Japanese low-altitude bombers, with Zero escorts, zoo over the field, blasting the clusters of American warplan whole squadrons taken out with one bomb. The mechanics and pilots, caught in the open, run from th strafing. The Zeros rake them down with machine gun fire. It's carnage.
Sammy, the amateur photographer, is leaving his house for morning of working his "Pictures of Paradise" business, w he sees the Japanese formations rumbling toward Pearl. He races back inside.
He fishes into his drawer for a film camera, and digs out cans of film, struggling to load it as he runs back out.

The pilots of Danny's squadron have returned from their n of drinking and brawling and are crashed on their bunks. stirs and staggers toward the head; he bumps into the wal backs up like a wind-up toy and lurches blindly forward again, into --

Red sleepwalks to the urinals and unleashes a marathon pi stream, still in his sleep. A rumble penetrates his brain and his eyes come open a fraction. Through the window sli above the urinals, he can see a cloud of Japanese planes rushing past. He squeezes his eyes shut, and looks again; the planes st bombing the distant hangers. Red pisses along the wall as he races to the barracks, tr to get his pecker back into his drawers. He shouts to the sleeping guys --
Th-th-th-th-th- He slaps his face with both hands, and stomps his feet...
Th-th-th-th-Dammit! Th-th-th- He still can't get it out, can't wake them; bursting with frustration, he suddenly blasts out singing --

(singing) The Jaaaps!! The Jaaaps!! He's belting it like a baritone in a bizarre opera. His friends stir; what the hell? Red points outside and tries talk, but now he can't mutter a syllable. The guys hear t explosions, and realize...

The pilots stagger out, half drunk, half dressed. Seeing what's happening, they race toward the flight line, where clustered American planes are blowing up in groups, and t pilots are knocked to the ground.
Goddamn Japs! Billy jumps to his feet and starts to run toward a cluste fighters that hasn't gone up yet.

Billy! Anthony tries to grab him and drag him back to earth but misses; Billy gets a few steps before the fire froma strafing Zero catches up to him; his friends watch in hor as Billy gets shorter as he runs; the Zero's machine gun is sawing his legs off from the feet up. Billy falls, legless but still alive; then a bomb falls almost on top of him, sending body parts over the pilots. Their innocence, like America's, is gone in that moment.

Danny and Rafe are in Danny's Buick, hung over and asleep Danny in front, Rafe in back, and they're a miserable sig -- their shirts ripped, blood dried in a leak trail from side of Rafe's nose and the corner of Danny's mouth. The rumble of planes moving overhead makes them stir; the rumble grows huge, as the shadows of a massive formation makes the sunlight flicker. Danny and Rafe squint up, the heads pounding, and realize what they're seeing. Suddenly their headaches are gone, and Danny's gunning the Buick d the road, toward the base.

Danny blasts through the main gate; the guards are too bu taking cover and haven't even closed the barrier. He races to the tarmac, where some of the planes are stil undamaged. Rafe is out the door before the car stops rolling, and Danny's right behind him. They're running toward a cluster of fighters, when it goe with a bomb blast. Rafe and Danny dive at each other; the first instinct is to cover their best friend with their o bodies. They look at each other on the ground. They see machine g bullets thudding into the planes on the flight line, and ripping along the walls of the buildings. It's as if the whole Japanese airforce is attacking this one base, and n leaving a single plane airworthy.
Get me into a plane!
Come on! Danny sprints; Rafe follows. Danny reaches a phone booth, and digs a dime from his pants.
You're making a phone call?! Danny dials, as waves of bullets sweep the area, and more planes blow up on the flight line. Rafe thinks he's lost mind.

(into phone) This is Walker! We're under attack! Get those planes fueled and armed RIGHT NOW! He runs back toward the car; Rafe, in the nonsense of bat reaches in to hang up the receiver, before Danny grabs hi and leads him on a sprint to the car, as the phone booth shatters behind them from the strafing. On the way to the car they dive back to the ground to avo strafing -- and see their friends lying nearby, in shock.
They got Billy.
Come with us! He and Rafe jump up and run again. Anthony, Red, and seve other pilots reach the Buick and dive in. Danny drives aw through the strafing.
Where are we going?
Auxiliary field at Haleiwa, ten miles north of here.
What's there?
Six P-40's. As the Zero pilots see the Buick moving, they go after it Danny drives like a madman through the strafing, zigzaggi and gunning the Buick's V-8.

The number of attacking planes seems endless -- and their strategy flawless. Torpedoes hitting one ship lifts its h with a blast, enabling the next wave of torpedoes to rush under and hit the next ship anchored behind. The American battleships are bobbing like see-saws. The OKLAHOMA takes an entire barrage of torpedoes, blowin thirty foot holes along it's hull; the ship immediately  begins to list.
Doors are wedged shut by the deformation of the structure vertical ladders are becoming horizontal, and water is pouring in. Men fight their way up against the water.
Water is up to the trapped sailor's waists when they grab wrench and start taking turns pounding $.0.S. in Morse co on the bulkhead.

As the listing grows more severe, sailors start jumping f the deck into the water. Still the Marines on deck are firing back at the planes; some Marines are even using handguns. But courage does not save them...

The men still on its deck try to run, but it's not just t fires and the water they can't escape; the gun turrets’ 1 pound shells break loose with the capsizing of the ship a tumble through everything like massive wrecking balls. The sailors and marines, thrown into the water, struggle get away from the suction as the giant battleship turns turtle. BELOW THE WATER men are sucked down with amazing force, e hair on their heads streaming behind them as they're snat to the depths. INSIDE THE OKLAHOMA, everyone and everything is spilling upside down. The ship's generators sputter out and the lights go out. The flashlights of the few sailors who can find them cut raggedly through the darkness, and water sp in. There is no escape. BELOW THE WATER, the Oklahoma's superstructure hits botto some men are crushed there. For others it's salvation, as the BACKWASH blows them toward the surface. ON THE SURFACE the men are launched almost completely out the water, before splashing back into the water and burni oil. A few feet of the steel hull and a portion of the propeller protrude above the surface, but most of the Oklahoma is under water. Men in the water swim toward a medical launch carrying wounded away from the wreckage. A bomb hits the launch an blows body parts everywhere.

In one compartment there are a dozen trapped men. They'v survived the roll-over, and are in a chaotic world where floor is now the ceiling. The water is up their waists. Some of the SAILORS are panicking. One sailor has a flashlight and switches it on, flashing light from face to face.
Don't panic! Don't panic!
The water's rising! It's coming up, we're all gonna drown!

The air pressure will equalize it! But the water keeps rising, along with their fears. Sever of the sailors are still screaming... The water's already to their bellies. One of them grabs a wrench and starts slamming Morse code against the bulkhea One sailor in the middle of the room is particularly panicked, not just yelling but crying and whimpering --
Get me out! Get me out!
Stop it! Come on! Save your air!

He's at the lower end of the compartment, where the water deeper -- the ship's nose is lower than her stern. The water's up to the guy's neck. The man with the flashlight dives down, and finds the guy foot wedged together in the pipes of the ships ceiling -- their floor. He pops up again. The water's up to the trapped guy's mou he's already gagging.

Is there a hacksaw in that locker?! They open it; tools spill out -- among them is a hacksaw. They hand it to him; the sailor dives down and cuts off t guy's foot. The trapped man is underwater, muffling his scream. He co free, and surfaces gasping. His severed foot floats to th  surface and then the horror really hits them. The sailor with the flashlight pops up, in the blossoming of blood. and another sailor tie a tourniquet around the stump, to the bleeding. The drama of this has caused the other trapped men to sto their signaling. Now they start banging, twice as loudly before.

Haleiwa is a tiny airfield, tucked among the green volcan hills; its barely paved, and it's only permanent building a quonset hut. A mechanic named EARL, is out with the P-40's; and these are spread out, not bunched.

The planes here have received loving care from Earl -- wh means lots of cursing; as he's wrestling to load an ammo belt, he yells. Sum-bitch! The Buick, bullet holes punched through the truck, slides a stop near the planes, and the pilots jump out.
They ready, Earl?
They'll all fly, but -- oh, shit... What stops him is the cloud of Zeros and dive bombers, shrieking in.

Cover! The guys scatter. There are sandbags around the hut, and they run there, diving into it's shelter just before the first strafing pass, when a Zero strafes one of the P-40' and a dive bomber blasts another. Earl stands up in shock and fury.
You absolute mother-fuckin' son of a bitch! You shot one of my planes! Danny pulls him down, as the Zeros roar overhead.
This ain't a little feud, Earl, it's World War Two!
They're coming around for another pass. You got extra weapons and ammo?
Cock-suckin' right I do!! In the gun lockers!
You guys get those! Earl, Rafe, come with me! Danny, Rafe and Earl run to the planes that got hit and s out the 20mm cannons and ammo.
The other pilots run in, throw open the gun locker, and s grabbing weapons -- aircraft machine guns, ammo belts, on even grabs a rifle.
The two groups run back and start to set up.

Danny, over there! We're in a canyon, they'll come straight down it, we'll get ‘em in a crossfire. Danny, Rafe and Earl run to a gully opposite the shed and up there, as the other pilots brace the machine guns agai the sandbags. The Japanese planes attacks again. This time the lead pla hits a wall of steel fired from the combined guns; the bullets chew into the bomb it carries and the plane EXPLO The airborne debris makes the following planes shear off. Red's standing, firing; he yells at the Zeros --
D-don't like it when we fight back, do ya! Red runs out with his machine gun and keeps firing even w the planes have passed, trying to shoot them right up the ass.
Earl! You said the planes were ready but -- but what?
Of the four left, only one is full of fuel.
Will the others get into the air? Earl shoots a look to Rafe, then turns to Danny.
Danny, I don't like this fuckin' guy.
Anthony, Red, stay with the guns! Coma, you cover the cannons! Joe, Theo, come with us! Earl, you get on the radio! We're gonna fight these fuckers. Two of the pilots, Joe and Theo, run to Danny.
How do we do it?
Your call, Rafe.

Get rolling as fast as you can. Stay low! We'll use the topography to separate them and then we can take 'em one on one. They race toward the planes, and the Japanese attack agai Seeing the pilots running for the P-40's, the Zeros aim f them; Rafe and Danny race for the most distant of the pla Joe and Theo run for the closer planes, through the dusty bullet hits. Theo makes his plane and is just strapping himself in whe bullets stitch his fuselage, wounding him. He still force the plane forward. He taxis twenty feet and his cockpit g chopped up and the plane arches into a right turn and put to a stop, Theo dead at the controls. Joe doesn't bother to strap in; he hits the throttle hard heads down the runway... The Zeros are on him as he gets ten feet of air at 120 M. The Zero's bullets eat his canopy and plane skin; the pla breaks apart in mid air, spilling in gouts of flame as it smashes down on the tarmac. Rafe and Danny have reaches the more distant P-40's and a revving their engines as they see Joe and Theo's fate. Th throw on their radio headsets. Their way seems blocked: they've got no runway behind the the wreckage of four P-40's scattered ahead of them, and Zeros screaming over the low hills to attack them. Now Ra and Danny talk through the radio.
It's tight.

Tighter 'n a bulls ass in fly season. Don't hit the barn. They gun their engines and roll through the grass on eith side of the runway, dodging the burning planes; they lift off, clearing the quonset hut by a couple of inches. They blow right through the strafing fire, and into the sky. Eight Zeros are all over them. Earl is in the hut, on the radio and watching through binoculars.
I see six...seven...eight of the cocksuckers! Don't let ‘em hurt my planes. Danny's swiveling in his seat, looking left, right, back.
They're all over us!

Bet they don't dust crops in Japan. Danny understands immediately, following Rafe's tactic as breaks into a sharp turn and uses the hut, palm trees, an low hills to shake the Japs. They fly like crop dusters, skimming down a foot from the ground, then bobbing up, banking left and right. The Zeros have divided into two groups to chase them, their wings clipping tree tops as t try to follow the Americans. It feels like a 200 M.P.H. car chase, 20 feet off the gro Rafe and Danny skimming and bobbing over the terrain, but there are too many Japanese.
Danny! Let's play some chicken! Danny banks in one direction, Rafe in another...

The two P-40's are screaming, rushing at each other like did at the training base back in the states, flying right into each other's propellers; the Japanese heading after realize they're rushing headlong at the other group...

Oh shit, oh shit... He can't even watch. At the last instant Rafe and Danny snap a quarter spin s planes flash by belly to belly. Two of the Zeros collide in mid-air, exploding, as the ot Zeros scatter.

Danny and Rafe rejoin each other in the open sky; they've lost the Zeros. The P-40's are flying smoothly, side by side. The two pilots look across at each other, going int battle together. They speak through their radios.
You hear my okay?
Yeah. So you can call me if you need help.
I got a half a tank. You?
Little less. He fires a short burst to see if his guns work; they do. Rafe does the same. Up ahead they see a formation of Japanese planes, headed toward Pearl.
They're in strafing formation, we'll blow right through their line. They look across at each other.
Land of the free.
Home of the brave. Side by side the P-40's scream in.

The Japanese planes are in tight, disciplined formation, their minds on the targets below them in the harbor. But their day of shooting sitting ducks changes as the two P- blast in, wing guns blazing, chopping into Two Zeros. Bot Zeros falter and begin to lose altitude. The P-40's make almost impossible tight turns, still side-by-side, and go after the two plane they crippled on the first pass. Rafe finishes one Zero, making it explode in a ball of fl in the air. Danny finishes the other, shooting off its wi  so that it spirals into the sea and crashes there. The P-40's swoop up again.

They're trying to hold formation. We can chew ‘em up! The P-40's dig in again, swooping down on the line of Zer Rafe hits first, machine gunning one plane, and Danny com in behind it, finishing it off. The Japanese pilots are screaming at each other over thei radios, but their SQUADRON COMMANDER sees Pearl Harbor ah and tells them --
Hold the line! The P-40's come through again, their guns spitting fire.

These planes are different -- high altitude bombers with three-man crews, high above the harbor. The bombardier lo through his sight and the bomb bays open. THROUGH THE BOMBARDIER'S SIGHT, the ships look like tops, below. The bombardier is ticking off the targets as they pass, the first two he mentions already burning.
West Virginia... Oklahoma... Ah, Arizona. He flips his bomb switch, and a HUGE STEEL BOMB falls awa

We stay with the bomb as it falls through the sky. The sm propeller on the bomb's nose spins in the air, running th arming mechanism into the bomb's explosive core. The bomb wobbles a bit at first, but then as it gathers speed its stabilize it, and it falls faster and faster, at a dizzyi rate, toward the Arizona. It slams through the teak wood deck, and breaks it like matchsticks. It's tremendous weight and speed carry it through the nex deck, and the next, deep into the heart of the ship...tow the powder room, where two million pounds of black powder waiting. The bomb hits there, and the explosion is almost beyond comprehension. Over 1400 men die instantly.

The battleship Arizona leaps into the air, the ship's sp is broken, it's guts ripped open in one explosive instant Men on the deck are thrown into the burning oil already floating on the water from the other ruptured ships, but there are almost no survivors. The concussion of the explosion blows men off the repair Vestal, next to the Arizona, saving Vestal, as the explos snuffs out the fires on Vestal; it also sends tons of deb down on her decks -- parts of the ship, legs, arms and he of men, all sorts of bodies. Debris from the Arizona also cover the Tennessee and does more damage than the two Japanese bombs that hit her.
Medics have already started bringing in the wounded. Evel is like a frantic traffic cop.
Put criticals in ward one, stables in two! Barbara! Fill every syringe you can find with stimulant and antibiotic --
Where are the doctors?
On the third tee.
Evelyn! Where's the morphine?

Evelyn runs in, snaps open the cabinet, grabs a bag of morphine sticks, and is about to run out again when she s the Arizona go up. For a moment she's frozen, then she actually sees the sho wave traveling across the bay and through the trees like invisible wall. She's trying to cross her arms over her face, and dive to the floor, just as the windows blow out from the concussion, and glass flies over everything.
They see the results of their bomb, and are ecstatic.

The nose of Danny's plane is pointed right at the harbor he sees the sudden devastation of the Arizona. It is a si so awesome it freezes him for a moment. A Zero comes up behind him, firing. Danny jerks his stic maneuver but he's caught... Rafe comes in behind the Zero, chopping it up, even as he yells at Danny over the radio --

Ain't no time for spectatin'! They turn back after the line of Zeros. There are some Japanese planes coming after them now, but the P-40's hea their noses, firing, then duck past in a double maneuver, turn right back into the Japanese formation. Rafe has a plane in his sights, but his guns fire only a short burst before stopping.
I'm out of ammo!

I'm out of fuel! They head back. A single Zero is on their way. Rafe charg it and draws its fire; Danny comes in behind the Zero and rakes its cockpit; the Japanese pilot backs off. The P-40's dive back toward Haleiwa. A handful of Zeros returning from Pearl see them and foll
The second wave of planes takes off from the carriers.
Genda reports to Yamamoto.
Second attack wave is in the air.
The DISC JOCKEY, handed a message by the army officer, st playing the soothing Hawaiian music and announces...
All Army, Navy, and Marine personnel to report to duty.
General SHORT is in his office; he and his aides are work frantically.
Mobilize everything! We're at war! Send a message to Washington: Hostilities with Japan commenced with an air raid on Pearl Harbor.
President Roosevelt is having lunch in the Oval Room stud with Harry Hopkins. The phone RINGS and Hopkins answers.
Oval Room... Yes, he is. (to Roosevelt) It's Knox, Mr. President.
(taking phone) Yes? He listens, then puts the receiver down, shaken.
The Japanese have attacked Pearl Harbor.
My God. Do we have damage estimates?
Our Pacific Fleet, at anchor, unprepared? It's terrible. It has to be. And it's not over.

The two P-40's drop out of the sky and bounce to a landin Anthony and Red have been pushing the wreckage off the fi with the Buick. Danny and Rafe pull the P-40's behind the burning quonset hut, and it's like a pit stop at a race track; Earl rushes up and starts fueling the planes, thei engines still running.
We need ammo too! Earl shouts instructions to the pilots.
Strip it from the wrecks! The other pilots race to the wrecked P-40's and start pul out ammo belts. Earl glares at the smoking engine of Dann plane, and the bullet holes.
Who the fuck taught you to fly?

He did. Earl looks at Rafe's plane, more shot-up and abused than Danny's. Rafe grins and waves to him. Earl mumbles a stre of guttural and unintelligible obscenities. The Zeros that followed them sweep down, strafing. One mechanic, running across the field with a belt of ammo, g down. Coma, running behind him, picks up the fallen man's ammo and his own, bringing both to the planes behind the He, Red, and Anthony reload the machine guns in Rafe and Danny's planes. Rafe and Danny gun their engines and head back into the a the grounded pilots firing a covering barrage and Earl ev coming up with a 12-gauge shotgun to fire at the Zeros as they rush past.
The Second Wave of Japanese planes is in tight formation.
Lt. Commander SHIMAZAKI, leader of the second attack wave says calmly into his radio...
Second wave, deploy over the military bases. High level bombers to the air stations, dive bombers attack ships in harbor. Fighters strafe and cover. He leads the second wave in on their attack run...
The navy's planes, bunched up on the naval airfield, are destroyed without ever getting into the air.

The harbor is already a mass of destruction and panic; screaming everywhere, men trying to fight fires, move the wounded; the second wave of planes hits, and tremendous explosions now rock the secondary ships like the destroye SHAW, blasting it apart. But the Japanese pilots are now having trouble with the t black smoke coming out of the damaged ships, and off the fires along the water. One torpedo plane, its pilot flyin blind, clips the superstructure of a battleship and spins a crash. Still, even IN THE CHAOS ON THE SHIPS, the sailors strugg to survive, inventively. Men trapped on one burning ship the severed barrel of a five-inch naval gun as a bridge t  cross to the less damaged ship anchored beside them. Others jump into the water and swim through the burning o towing buddies too wounded to swim themselves.

Below decks, sailors have organized a line and are passin ammunition from the ammo lockers, hand to hand up to the on deck. Blasts from bombs hit them and ignite the ammo they're holding, setting off a chain reaction of explosio On the deck, the sailors are out of ammo. An OFFICER grab SEVENTEEN YEAR OLD SAILOR.
Grab a dinghy and get ammo from the base ammo storeroom. The young sailor jumps to a dinghy and launches it throug the oily waters and thick black smoke.

The sailors in the boat get strafed, the rounds cutting between them and blasting their boat in two. They jump in the oily water and swim toward shore. Other sailors are in the water with them, struggling, swallowing the vile black liquid as they battle to swim. Errant bombs and shrapnel hit beside them, killing some; other lose strength and slide beneath the surface. The sailors from the ammo boat make it ashore; it's hot t too, with bullets and bombs all around. One sailor has to stop and puke from the oil; his buddy grabs him and they for cover; they find it in the dugout of the baseball diamond.
A MARINE GUNNERY SERGEANT leads men in a race through strafing fire to the bases ammo storeroom.
The SUPPLY SERGEANT is at his post.
We need weapons and ammo!
You need authorization.
The fuck I do! He pushes the man out of the way and starts grabbing wea
The gunnery sergeant and his marines run with a water-coo machine gun, across the open ground, under fire.
The Marines set up in the windows of their already-strafe barracks, and start firing there, as the Zeros scream pas
Trucks are moving dependents -- women and children -- fro the dependents’ housing area. The Japanese strafe the trucks, dependents diving for cover.

A fire engine from the Honolulu Fire Department races up the sight of buildings burning from the air attack. As th firemen jump out, a Zero strafes them, gunning down the firemen. As the strafing Zero starts to bank away, two P-40's come behind it, both of them gunning away. The Zero comes apar under the barrage, and crashes in a ball of flame. It's Rafe and Danny, back in the air.

The once-pristine hospital with its glowing white beds is a bloody chaos. Every bed is already full; there are burn and broken people on the floor -- soldiers, sailors, civilians, firemen, all mixed in together. People are dyi everywhere, and screaming in pain, or moaning and begging help. At first we don't see Evelyn, and wonder if she survived the glass; then we see her, flecks of her own bl dotting her face and arms. The blood of soldiers on her surgical apron. A steel calm has replaced her earlier frenzy, even as the other nurses are breaking down.
I can't tell who's gotten morphine and who hasn't!
Take a grease pencil and mark an M on the forehead of everyone you stick. A young doctor is trying to give an intravenous injection a man who's badly charred; the doctors hands are shaking.
Don't look for a vein, just poke.
My pen's dry!

Use lipstick. Use ammo belts for tourniquets, use your own nylons if you have to! Barbara! Grab anything that will hold a pint of blood and sterilize it. The doctors are amputating limbs right there in the hallw A SENIOR DOCTOR calls --

Evelyn! You have to do the triage! They're bringing them in with trucks! Evelyn moves to the door. Trucks are pulling up, loaded w the wounded, young terrified soldiers bringing them insid Evelyn does quick triage as they pass.

Critical -- front ward!... Give him morphine, he can't wait... The next body through is a pilot, wings on his uniform, h chest riddled with bullets -- and his face shot off. For moment Evelyn falters, then she forces herself to check t dog tags... It isn't Rafe or Danny. Evelyn sags in guilty relief.

Take him outside and cover him; he's dead. She steadies herself as the next body comes through, a wo on a stretcher, her stomach shot open, pale hands clutchi at the open wound, Evelyn feels for a pulse.

She's gone too, take her -- It's Betty. And though the bombs are blasting and guns booming everywhere, the world goes silent for Evelyn. One of the sailors outside the door is pointing to the harbor, the Nevada has begun to move.
The battleship NEVADA is underway, plowing through the harbor, as the water erupts with bombs.
The Captain is struggling to save his ship.
We can save her if we make the open sea!
The lead pilot in the next squad of Japanese planes spots moving battleship, and leads his squadron on it. They come whipping in over the waves, dropping torpedoes bombs.
The Nevada's Captain feels the ship shudder as it takes h amidships.
We're not gonna make it -- and if we go down here we block the channel... Beach her, there! His officers relay the order to the helm, and the ship's rudder turns as more blasts rip her hull.
The Nevada swings off its course and runs aground.
The impact jolts the boilers, already bursting with the s pressure; gouts of steam from rupturing pipes scalds and blinds the engine room crew.

The Nevada, run aground at the shoreline, is now like a b cut from the herd; the predators swarm after it with torpedoes and bombs. One torpedo, missing the Nevada, skims right up the beach itself and blasts a house on the shore to fragments. Bombs detonate along the Nevada, engulfing the entire upp deck in flames, ravaging the sailors.

The Nevada is grounded near the hospital; from the doorwa Evelyn can see the whole ship on fire, burning sailors leaping off the decks. Her hearing, her presence of mind, returns; she lets Betty go, and grabs an ORDERLY.
Go to the base hardware store and get some of those canister spray things they use for killing bugs.
Insecticide?

No, just the sprayers. We'll fill them with tannic acid, it'll sterilize them and cool the burns! GO! The orderly races away. They can still hear the bombs falling outside. A sailor staggers toward the hospital from the Nevada. He completely gray. Everyone stares at him, and then realize he is nude, burned gray, his skin ash. Evelyn rushes to help him, shouting back over her shoulde the other nurses --
We're gonna need every bed. If they can breathe, make 'em get up and move someplace else!
The first wave of planes lands on the carrier. The flight leader rushes to the bridge.
Yamamoto's advisors are exultant.
We have achieved complete surprise! The first wave is returning, the second is attacking now, and we have lost only a few planes. We can launch a third wave, Admiral.
The second wave has not returned. And we have no idea where their carriers are. What is the damage report?
We have Commander Fuchida on the radio now, Admiral. Yamamoto nods and Fuchida's voice comes over the intercom
I am over the harbor now...

Fuchida is in a scout plane, high over Pearl. His vision hampered by the thick black smoke, but he can tell there been awesome devastation. He uses a diagram of the ships anchor to note the damage to each ship.
(into radio) We have a tremendous victory. Many ships damaged, some totally destroyed. But the Second Wave's attack is being hindered by the smoke.
The more we attack, the harder it is to find targets. And we no longer have surprise.
If we launch the third wave and annihilate their fuel depots, we destroy their ability to operate in the Pacific for at least a year!
And if we fail, and lose our carriers, we destroy our ability to fight them at all. (beat) As soon as the second wave returns, we will withdraw.
The last planes touch down, and the lead carrier and the other ships in the Japanese assault fleet turn back towar home.

The harbor is a place of shattered bodies and shattered ships. Blood, body parts, debris everywhere, and all of i made more hellish by the oil fires on the water and the choking black smoke those fires produce. Every survivor has become an emergency fireman, stretcher bearer, medic, iron worker. They fish men from the water, extract them from the tangled wreckage of the ships. Everyone is screaming and yelling -- the wounded for help the helpers for more help. Local firemen and civilians battle heroically too; the wa mains are ruptured, so they put pump water from the base swimming pool toward the burning ships. The PHOTOGRAPHER records this with his black-and-white f camera. He is shaken, and yet he understands the magnitud of what he is recording -- the loss of America's innocenc
In one place, outside a barracks, soldiers hit by the bom are just becoming conscious. One of them comes to.

Sarge?! Where are you, Sarge? He's crawling around toward the bushes; his legs are shattered, but he's spotted a body. He reaches it, turns over -- and it's headless. He turns away in horror...and finds himself staring at th severed head. The medics appear.
We've got two more over here!
The Western Union messenger, Tadao Fuchikami, delivers th telegram from Washington.
Short and his staff are assessing damage.
I want lookouts and sentries everywhere, with orders to shoot first and ask questions later.
You think an invasion possible, General?
After this morning, we better not consider anything impossible.
An aide hands Short the telegram. He reads it -

From Washington. “Intelligence reports an ultimatum from Japan to be given precisely at one p.m. Washington time. Just what significance the hour set may have we do not know, but be on alert accordingly." The irony is bitter in his throat.
The Honolulu police roar up to the embassy in squad cars, burst through the doors.
The police storm through the embassy and find the Japanes there burning documents.

Divers are going down, trying to save the trapped men. Bu the tangle of the Arizona is horrific. One diver gets trapped, and another tries to extricate him, and the stee shifts and falls on them both. ON THE DECK OF BOMB-SHATTERED BATTLESHIP, a naval CAPTAIN oversees rescue efforts. The 17-year-old sailor he sent o for ammo now approaches him, with great concern.
Sir, I...I lost the dinghy. The captain looks out over the wreckage, great battleship devastated in every direction.
Well, son, we won't worry about the dinghy today.
Danny and Rafe arrive at the hospital. Their fears of wha they might find aren't helped when they see the stairs in the hospital covered in blood.

Rafe and Danny enter. It's a scene from hell. Doctors are doing amputations in the hallway. The once-pristine hospi is now all red, with blood dripping through the mattresse onto the floor... In the main ward, Evelyn and the other nurses are using t fly sprayers to spritz cooling antiseptic on the charred bodies. Evelyn looks up and sees both Rafe and Danny. Her eyes register relief, but they are the only part of her t can show emotion now; the rest of her is covered in blood Rafe and Danny move to her.
How can we help?
Rafe and Danny sit quietly as Evelyn adjusts the tubes conducting blood from their arms into sterilized Coke bot for transfusion.
What else can we do?
There's nothing you can do here, they'll die or they won't, we just -- She stops, afraid if she says more, she'll lose grip on h emotions. She can see the wreckage out in the harbor.
There was a sailor, a black man on the West Virginia, named Dorie Miller. I'd like to know if he's alive. She goes back to her work.
Rafe and Danny hop from the ambulance in which they've hitched a ride to the harbor. They see the awful devastation.
Rafe and Danny reach the West Virginia's pier, but in the darkness, they can't find anything. They stop a NAVAL OFFICER.
Where is the West Virginia?

There. He points; the battleship has sunk, its superstructure ba showing above the water. It looks hopeless to find a single sailor here; but then see a powerful black sailor, pulling to the dock with a dinghy full of dead men retrieved from the water.
